                "_type": "review",
                "_source": {
                    "votes": {
                        "funny": 0,
                        "useful": 1,
                        "cool": 2
                    },
                    "user_id": "wOSHvuJEJflUEesNLno51A",
                    "review_id": "MDwdZbIL6in-x_TUCwcQmQ",
                    "text": "The Varsity is a frankfurter legend, built on chili, coleslaw, and the phrase \"What'll ya have?\".  It doesn't serve up the best hot dog you'll ever have, but they have a solid dog menu.  \n\nThe menu is mainly based around the chili cheese dog, which comes with american cheese, mustard, and Varsity brand chili.  The chili is decent and meaty, but not very spicy.  You could say the chili doesn't take anything away from the hot dog, but without some spice or strong flavor, the chili isn't adding much either.  Instead, it's the combo of the mustard and the chili that sells the hot dog.  The american cheese slice was tucked into the bun and didn't really melt into the chili--that's the main negative I have for the dog.  The cheese mostly remained separate from the chili and didn't add anything to the mix.\n\nIf you're a coleslaw fan, try a chili slaw dog.  I had a \"slaw dog\" -- simply a hot dog with coleslaw on it.  The coleslaw itself was diced and lightly sweetened.  It wasn't bad, but wasn't particularly remarkable as a slaw.  So I'd recommend ordering a chili dog with slaw so that you're not relying on the slaw alone for flavor.\n\nOnion rings were super greasy, but flaky.  The fried coating was thick and smooth and left a light grease stain on everything it touched.\n\nThe Varsity's been around for a long time and has lots of traditions for visitors to experience/read about.  The most prominent tradition is that the staff greets customers with the customary \"What'ch y'all want\".  Given it's history and decent tasting dogs, this place is worth a visit.\n\nBottom line: 3 1/2 stars for the food.  Add in 1/2 a star for the tradition (it is the South after all).",

The Hot Link is an apt description, because it's nice and spicy. The grilled bun takes the hot dog to another level.  Just writing this review is making me crave one!\n\nThe people who work here are definitely characters, sometimes you get a guy who is super-friendly and jovial, and sometimes you get a guy who is all business and yells at the customers to not crowd the doorways.\n\nSpeaking of crowding the doorways, the shop is so small, it's almost impossible to not crowd the doorway.             {
                "_type": "review",
                "_source": {
                    "votes": {
                        "funny": 2,
                        "useful": 1,
                        "cool": 2
                    },
                    "user_id": "y6cy0wfDyqb7CNUVlMUwWw",
                    "review_id": "QXN96tUhE98s_iaBFxbHkw",
                    "text": "Was I the only one who always thought \"being in the dog house\" was a bad thing?  Seriously ... I would have engaged in a lot more mischievous hijinks as a kid if I had known that my only potential punishment was a mouth-watering, juicy sausage, smothered in grilled onions and jalapeno peppers, layered up with dijon mustard and curry ketchup, and placed gently on a crispy, sweet french roll.  So for this week's grubbing session we knocked over a few mailboxes and spray-painted the cat blue ... and landed ourselves in Pasadena's Dog Haus. \n\nThe place has a cool, open, classed-up vibe with long wood tables, a cart loaded up with hot dog fixins, and a giant menu board tempting you with a cornucopia of devilishly creative hot dog and sausage concoctions.  Our grub mate H. Dawg, went for the Sooo Cali topped with mixed greens, diced tomatoes, crispy tempura fried onion strips, a spicy basil aioli, and avocado all loaded into a few soft squares of King's Hawaiian bread.  If you've never had the super-soft Hawaiian delight ... or never had a hot dog on it for that matter ... you've never really lived. \n\nOurselves, we battled back and forth ... resisting the desire to dive into one of their out-of-control (in a good way) hot dogs that are loaded up with toppings such as thick (and we mean thick ... like \"measure it with a ruler\" thick) sliced bacon, eggs, and tatter tots ... or another with chili-con-carne and a sprinkle of Fritos chips.  Eventually we landed on one of the house specials ... the \"Best of the Wurst\" ... we went with the bratwurst and loaded up the aforementioned grilled onions and jalapeno peppers.  Everything was taste-tastic ... from the flavor packed brat to the soaking-up-the-juices, just a-little-bit-of-sweetness and a-little-bit-of-crunch french roll. \n\nTo match up with our dogs, we went with an order of their super sized onion rings and the side dish of every 11 year old's dreams ... tater tots.  Now I know why Napoleon saved 'em up in his cargos pockets and was hesitant to give them away.  These crispy, salty, cylindrical morsels of grub-delight are a magical accompaniment to any meal ... a perfect device to dunk into that craving-inducing curry ketchup (seriously ... if they don't have it out on the fixins cart ... ask for it) and pop into your soon-to-be-dancing mouth. \n\nOf course we also added a bottle of Mexican Coke to our order.  Some say the deliciousness comes from the real sugar instead of corn syrup ... others firmly believe it's the glass bottle that makes it so damn good.  But deep down we all know the real reason ... unicorn powder.  Whatever it is, we just love the stuff ... especially when you're matching it up with the gut-busting, mind-blowing, heaven-on-a-bun coming out of the Dog Haus.  Each bite I felt myself channeling my inner Sean Connery and holding back the desire to shout out \"You're the man now dog!\"  But it's true ... and honestly Dog Haus, that's really the only way to describe it.  You are ... simply ... the man.",

                    "text": "It's kind of criminal to frequent a place 20 times a year and leave them no loving, while dropping notes left and right about places you visit once. I'm contrite, Oasis, and as a woman of action over words (just kidding--I'm really not at all) I'm giving you the e-hug you so richly deserve, with your \"Bubble Tea and Tater Tots\" specials, and your dirt cheap hot dogs with any bubble tea purchase. Please, Ave-travelers, do not be seduced by that \"gourmet\" hot dog place up the street. Pocket 8 of your 9 hot dog-earmarked buckages and get your dog on with a delicious milk tea. \n\nWhat they have: a large menu of both milk teas, traditional teas, fruit juice teas, and of course coffee, Jenga (all of whose pieces have enlightening quotes written by, yeah, college students, as well as the occasional piece decorated with a hand-drawn vulva or heavy metal hand), one poster of Angelina Jolie looking like an unremitting bitch, one poster of Johnny Depp wearing eyeliner and looking fashionably homeless, and 100% Asian patrons who may or may not include you.\n\nOh yes, and they've also got bang-up bubble tea. I love their boba--it's never gummy or slimy--and they've got varied flavor offerings. I've tried a lot of them, and keep netting out to the watermelon slushie with boba or the green tea bubble tea. I always ask for less sweet, and they always actually do make it less sweet.                     "text": "The negative reviews are totally clueless.  First, the chili dogs are the benchmark for all chili dogs.  \"Bad  chili,\" some yokel says.  OF COURSE, on it's own, but it's not supposed to be chili ON ITS OWN.  Most chili dogs are a competition between the hot dog and the chili, with the chili (usually with stupid beans) drowning the dog so you can't eat it without knife and fork.  The Varsity chili dog is a perfect balance between the bun, the dog, the chili and the mustard (and the optional fresh onions) -- and easy to fondle.  The rings and the fried pies are best-in-class.  But by nature they don't travel well.  If you order them to go, they WILL go limp or the crust soft by the time you get home.\n\nAnd that brings me to freshness.  EVERYTHING is fresh.  The Varsity invented \"just-in-time\" long before McDonald's.\n\nAlso, the other sandwiches....  Grow up and try the \"chili steak\" (chili burger to the newbies).  The others -- ham and swiss on rye, pimento, or house chicken salad -- are unique and delicious.\n\nThe frosted orange (NOT \"frozen\" orange) is a trademark milkshake.  The basis was an old non-carbonated soft drink called Bireley's and vanilla ice cream.  They used to make it from scratch but it now comes out like a hard slush.  Not as good today, but still a must for a Varsity pig-out.\n\nAs for prices, don't be ridiculous!  First, they sit on prime downtown real estate; second, business taxes in Atlanta are SKY-HIGH to cover the asses of the corrupt and incompetent city government.  Believe me, they don't wanna charge so much, but they have to.  So, think before you rant.\n\nSorry, Varsity trashers -- the problem isn't the Big V, it's you.                     "text": "Stopped in yesterday for lunch since we were in the hood and, needless to say, I had great expectations since they have the \"World's best pastrami or World's #1 pastrami\" or something like that.  How do I know that?  It was on the sign!!!\n\nThe setting reminds me of something straight out of the 70s.  Dark panel walls with matching booths.  I don't mind that as long as the food is good.  Being from the midwest it's kinda welcoming.  With all the panelling, there's still a lot of natural light so it's not cave-ish or anything.  \n\nThe line to order's almost out the door and it moved pretty quick.  The menu's on the backwall above the register and I notice that the sandwiches were pretty pricey ($7.79 each).  So my husband got the pastrami and I got the roast beef au jus.  With that we got a small fries and a small soft drink and a cup for water and our bill was almost $22. \n\nGot our food pretty quick and the fries, even though, they were a size small came in a brown paper bag and was almost half full.  There were plenty of fries and they were actually pretty good, but needless to say, both of us couldn't eat it all.  Apparently, you can top your fries with their gravy or chili but being first timers here, we just wanted the basics.  The sandwiches had the soft bread with the meat in it (his pastrami and mine roast beef) and that's it.  I got the au jus with my roast beef and that came in a covered cup.  The roast beef was soft and good, but the au jus tasted like watery soy sauce.  It was a tad salty and made the sandwich wet.  If that's all you want for your jus, it did the job.  I kept thinking something was missing.  I guess I shouldn't compare it to the same sandwiches in Chicago where there were cheese and peppers in there but I wanted to try it in its intended form but had to get extra peppers from the counter but, alas, no cheese in sight.  The pastrami was alright too.  Nothing extra-ordinary and my husband actually liked my roast beef more than his pastrami. \n\n I miss food like this when we travelled through Chicago and New York.  Full of flavors and came with everything on it.  There was hot dog on the menu too.  I was wondering what they put on the hot dogs here when you order one since all the condoments were in tiny packets on the front counter and not like those Chicago style hot dogs that once you ordered a dog, you would also get the pickles, relish, mustard, onions, tomatoes, ketchup handed to you and, of course, extra cheese to go with your fries as well.\n\nGlad I tried it and have checked it off my list.                     "text": "I had my reservations, but gave this place a try. It's kind of nice to have an Asian bakery around. It's something I missed and there isn't anything close to it around these parts. They have a wide selection of buns, some on the smaller side and most of a usual size. The coconut cream bun was soft and perfect, but gets stale quickly so eat it immediately after purchase. There are also hot dog and green onion buns, which is a favorite of mine. There's also a tuna bun that I've never had before, but liked. They also have minced meat puff pastry pies, which I like. They also have those cake rolls.                     "user_id": "j14WgRoU_-2ZE1aw1dXrJg",
                    "review_id": "7yQS86IVjZIO_XZAr9wwiw",
                    "text": "The Vortex makes a pretty mean burger.  Vortex Midtown was the first legit burger establishment I ate at when I first moved to Atlanta over 10 years ago, mainly due to it's proximity to Tech.  I still live nearby and over the years, this restaurant has proven to be a reliable standby for solid bar food.  They have a patio right on Peachtree, which makes it perfect for people watching.  And they're open late, most days until 2 to 3am.\n\nThe menu has over 20 different burger varieties and all sorts of delicious apps, such as their nacho tots.  My favorites include the aforementioned tots, sweet potato fries, fried zucchini slices, mini corn dogs, Vortex Bacon Cheeseburger, Tasmanian Devil Burger, Cowboy Burger, and the Big Nine-Inch Weenie.\n\nThe nacho tots are a messy conglomeration of tots, chili, shredded cheese, olives, lettuce, sour cream, and salsa.  It's good, and great for groups.  You can get it with regular nachos too, but the tots are better.  Vortex's sweet potato fries are among the best in the city.  They are crinkle-cut and served hot from the fryer.\n\nThe burgers are huge.  These ain't no FLIP or YEAH! burgers.  The sirloin patties are large, thick, and hearty.  Each burger comes with lettuce, sweet red onion, and tomato, a slice of pickle, and a side (fries, onion rings, chips, etc.).  And yes, you can get sweet potato fries as a side.  The Tasmanian Devil Burger comes with pepperberry rub, pepperjack cheese, and pineapple salsa.  The Cowboy Burger comes with grilled ham, jack cheese, and spicy honey BBQ sauce.  I haven't had a burger here that I didn't like except for the Black & Blue Burger (too much blue cheese for me).\n\nThe Big Nine-Inch Weenie is solid.  It's plump, thick, and all-beef.  Great flavor and consistency and very satisfying.  It's a big, filling hot dog.  I usually load mine up with coleslaw, raw onion, and sweet relish (no additional cost).  Other topping options include sauerkraut and sauteed onions.\n\nService is generally very good and the servers are friendly.  One of my favorite servers has been Elizabeth D. (pro-active, straight-laced, and good sense of humor). The atmosphere is a combination of bikers, skeletons, tattoos, and piercings.  Laughing Skull Lounge, a comedy club, is also located inside the restaurant.  You can read my review for the LSL here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/laughing-skull-lounge-atlanta#hrid:QrTygG6fzlDtLdnHyiBXzw.  Vortex does have an 18 and up age policy, which I like because you don't have a bunch of little kids running around making noise.\n\nMidtown Vortex is located caddy corner from the Starbucks on Peachtree.  There are several pay lots, parking decks, and street parking spots available close-by.  I recommend parking in the AmeriPark surface lot directly across the street ($5).",

                "_type": "review",
                "_source": {
                    "votes": {
                        "funny": 0,
                        "useful": 12,
                        "cool": 8

                    "user_id": "LYXc1p5VH4ny-KO2-W1_eQ",
                    "review_id": "GUeVUyhT_1Z_8_rR9MrJZQ",
                    "text": "Cuatro's is a great new contender in the casual-yet-upscale, patio-dining category.  Started by a crew of former Chuy's/Hula Hut/Shady Grove managers, Cuatro's kicks the food up about 10 notches from this chain and serves it in a much more modern, less touristy setting.  The result is pretty darn delightful.\n\nI had the shrimp and avocado tacos, which were terrific.  The shrimp was perfectly grilled and there was a generous portion of avocado.  It sported Cuatro's \"ubiquitous sauce\" (their name, not mine), which is a surprising mix of sriracha (or \"hot cock,\" as Yelper Delicious L. so aptly calls it), mayonnaise, salt and pepper.  The tortillas were nicely warmed and tasted very fresh.  The only thing that would have made it better was a little cabbage; I like the slight crunch and bitterness that cabbage adds to seafood tacos.  Two tacos a la carte ran me just $7.\n\nCuatro's also offers a pretty extensive selection of burgers, several other types of tacos (including a number of veggie options), and a few salads.  Sides appear to be extra for all dishes, but their pricing is sufficiently low to make that OK.  I did notice that they offer my weakness, sweet potato fries; I'll have to try those sometime when I'm feeling a little more splurge-y.\n\nThey have a pretty good selection of draft beers (plus my fave draft cider, Woodchuck Amber) and a full bar, so mixed drinks are an option, as well.  There are drink specials every night of the week.  The night I was here (Wed), they had $3 premium pints and $1.50 pints of the usual suspect domestics (Miller, Miller Lite, etc.).  Fridays, they have happy hour from 3 pm until close!  I don't remember all the Friday happy hour deals, but I do remember that it included $2 well drinks.  Now that's my kind of happy.\n\nGreat service, nice open patio that's dog friendly (yeah!), a little bit of free parking (key in West Campus), and reasonable prices.  The only thing I might suggest is that you avoid this place on big game days, as they have quite a few high def TV's and a giant projection TV right out front.\n\nAt first blush, Cuatro's rates a high four stars from me.  I'd give 'em 4-1/2 if I could.  I need at least one or two more visits to convince me to bump them up to the coveted five-star rating, but that's a distinct possibility.  Cuatro's is definitely worth a visit - check it out!\n\n------\nEDIT, 5/9/08:  Was back here for lunch with other Yelpers in tow.  Cuatro's didn't deliver quite as well as it had on my first visit.  Service was a little scattered (it was much more crowded), and the food wasn't as fabulous.  I tried the portabello burger, and it was really drippy - I had to give up about halfway through and eat it with a fork and knife.  We tried the sweet potato fries, which I liked fine, but I think I may have been the only one.  Since Don P. was there, we also had to have queso (of course), which was all right, but not amazing.  It was better when eaten with the salsa we requested to have with it.  My favorite part about this meal (other than the company) was the jalapeno ranch dressing, which was very homemade tasting and had a great zing.  I wanted to dip EVERYTHING in it.\n\nStill a four-star experience, but not the \"OMG this may be my new place\" four-plus star experience I had the first time around.  Nevertheless, I'm sure I'll be back, especially during those wonderful Austin patio-weather days.",

                    "text": "This is a very strange place - for those of you who saw *Book of Mormon,* Champion Pets belongs in \"that spooky Mormon Hell dream.\" \n\nThere is no shortage of nice pet boutiques and megastores in Pasadena, many with a great range of food and supplies and well-informed staff knowledgeable about animals and pet products: Centinela Pet Feed, Petsmart, Paw Boutique, etc...\n\nThere are also many great shelters and animal rescues in the area - Pasadena Humane Society, Paw Boutique, United Hope for Animals, Beagles and Buddies, and more-- looking for good homes for homeless pets, many of them purebred.\n\n. . .And then there is this store. Depressing. dark. oddly empty. Last time I walked by on a Saturday at noon (prime shopping hours on south lake!), they were not yet open. Staff doesn't seem to know much about their business or the community. They have a small selection; and yet their website makes the bizarre and false claim that \"by providing more brands and more products then any other independent store, we can eliminate the hassle of having to go store by store to get exactly what you need.\"  The website also says CP is a \"family owned business,\" but it provides no information about the  family that supposedly owns it, - not even their names or how to reach them if you have questions or concerns. There is a link to \"owners\" on their website - which takes you to lots of photos of people with their pets (presumably dogs they bought at the store, but who knows!).\n\n. . .And there are the dogs - I've seen them go for as much as $1800!  No good breeder would sell their dog through a pet store.  I feel sorry for the well meaning and unsuspecting people who come to this place, see a cute sad dog behind plexiglass, and then fork over nearly 2K..\n\n. . .And there is this weird sign - \"WE DO ADOPTIONS\" - meaning NOT that they work with rescues to help find homes for homeless pets, but rather that they will take your dog and  . . . supposedly find it a new home (?)\n\n I am glad to see the other reviewers on Yelp have also wondered about this place.  \n\nMy hope for Champion Pets is that  they will read their YELP reviews and realize they need to have a care; that they will make a commitment to being a good business and making a difference; that they will become more involved in the south lake neighborhood; and that they will work with animal lovers and owners, and rescues, and shelters, and vets to improve the lives of animals in their community.\n\nIf all else fails, perhaps the desire to have a more prosperous business will motivate this place to change.",

                    "text": "First off, I think it's really funny that the name of this place as far as Yelp is concerned is \"parlour\". While we can argue the merits of the chili and the ambiance I think we can all agree that this is a \"parlor\".\n\nI like this place a lot. The staff is genuinely friendly without making you feel like you are at Chotchkie's. The chili is excellent and not blazingly, cripplingly hot. This is good. I don't *like* chili that is too hot. The same mentality that complains about food that is not hot enough is the mentality that insists martini's don't have vermouth. A martini without vermouth is cold gin (which is fine, if that's what you like) and chili that is all hot and no flavor is a drag. If you need to prove your manliness by smirking at non-nuclear chili, well, go somewhere where the chili is equal parts Alpo and cayenne pepper and leave the rest of us alone. \n\nFor the record, the XXX is still pretty spicy. It will satisfy all but the most scarred palate.\n\nThe chili is not made with ground beef - it's big meaty chunks of beef. Very satisfying. Get the Frito pie, which is a big scoop of chili on a bed of Fritos sprinkled with cheese, onions and jalapenos. Delicious!\n\nI would call the decor and atmosphere \"calculated dive\".                     "text": "Stereotypically, college students stay up late & eat at all odd hours of the day. Unfortunately, most restaurants around Berkeley that are of the yummier variety close earlier in the night.\n\nSweetheart's hours are great. It's location on Durant Avenue in so-called \"Asian Ghetto\" is pretty convenient for Berkeley's dorm residents and apartment dwellers. Even if you live farther, if you're looking for FOOD, GREASE (the good kind?), and LIFE, you can generally find it at Ghetto or across the street at Top Dog or La Burrita.\n\nAlso, it is undeniable that Sweetheart uses way more NATURAL ingredients than a place like Quickly does. It isn't worth it to skimp quality for speed. Sweetheart keeps it real.\n\nYes, their menu can be confusing and repetitive. Yes, they don't offer some of the things ON their menu. But it is an OBVIOUS good choice for a place to hang out with friends or on the solo whether you'd like to sit down and chat or pass on through.\n\n[P.S.                     "review_id": "DI5zd9eFavFaR98UWtOYqg",
                    "text": "I give then 4 stars, but there are a couple of \"but's\"....\n\nPrana is your place for hot yoga. I am very new to yoga in general and very new to hot yoga, but each time I have been here (which is a handful at this point) I felt comfortable. The skill level of the participants varies so if you are intimidated by the person next to you doing headstands...well...I can't help you. I take breaks, I don't do some poses if it is too much for me and I feel completely okay doing that. \n\nThe instructors are all different as to be expected. Some focus more on meditation than others, some don't do much with meditation.  I like that in that each class feels different to me and not like I am doing the same thing over and over. However, the skill level of the classes tend to skew more intermediate than beginner so again, do what you can and don't worry if you can't do it all.\n\nIt is hot. Thus, the hot yoga. I have never sweat so much in my entire life, but I think that is a good thing. Bring water, a mat, a towel if you need. Come prepared to sweat.\n\nThe \"but's\".... Most classes are VERY crowded. The weekend AM classes especially. Part of this is due to the fact that they have run several daily deal specials. They have done Living Social and Rue La La that I know of. Hey, I came here through a Living Social. There are classes where there is almost no space between you and the next person, so be prepared for a sweaty butt in your face. I am okay with that, but if you don't like crowded, hot rooms this is not your ticket.\n\nAnother \"but\" is that the coat/shoe/putting yourself back together area is really small. So after class everyone is all over each other trying to get out of there. It can be hard especially since part of that area is right in front of the elevator. So, the studio space in that sense is tight. The yoga room itself is large and clean.\n\nOverall I like it here, it might be out of my budget after my Living Social, but we'll see. I would keep coming back (which is the goal of these Daily Deals, to get repeat customers, so in that sense, they will probably be successful with me).",

                    "text": "Does CI have the best Italian hoagie I've ever had? Negatory. Are they pretty much the only place I will eat in 30th St before catching the Amtrak to NY Penn Station? You know it. \n\nCI is a counter service deli/sandwich shop near the main terminal. They have a good selection of sandwiches and sides--some of the sides look incredible, in fact, like the marinated artichokes--and are very reasonably priced. They have a Subway-ish model of service, where you order a sandwich, they start to assemble it with pre-packs of meats, and then you point out which toppings you'd like on it. \n\nTheir Italian hoagie is not too bad, with mediocre bread (a little too soft), and decent meats.                     "text": "Stixs is an interesting concept poorly executed.\n\nAt first it seems obvious: meat on a stick in Texas? What could be better? \n\nBut then you walk through the door -- or more accurately, wade through the people squinting at the menu in the doorway. The poorly-designed menu takes some time to comprehend and since there is no table service, everyone gathers in the entryway. \n\nOnce you've decided, you order one or two skewers at about $7 a pop. Although there is no table service you are expected to leave a tip at the register when you order. I found this off-putting when paying with a credit card. Although I am an excessive tipper in most cases, I find it weird to ask for a tip just for placing an order.\n\nI ordered some Thai peanut skewers (these are most definitely not kabobs) in chicken and shrimp.                 "_type": "review",
                "_source": {
                    "votes": {
                        "funny": 2,
                        "useful": 3,

                    "user_id": "rbYZ89tFhgk93uQkTl799Q",
                    "review_id": "rQKh70V2wUzURui5bEGYCg",
                    "text": "I just had lunch and I feel the need to scrub my tongue with either corn bread or a nail file, then run ten miles in the heat. The food is THAT heavy. \nWhat no one mentions, and you may miss the sign at the order window: everything here is fried in LARD.  Yummy, I thought. The way chicken is meant to be fried.  Here, not so much. \n\nThe menu is basic, and touts the use of locally raised, organic poultry with some heft. Pieces are large; the crust hot and golden, the flesh juicy and tender. Two scents assaulted me as I took my first bites: garlic powder and that weird smell chicken on the bone has when it's not quite done. I find neither appealing. The second bite sent a deluge of hot liquid cascading down my forwarm; most of it grease.(All the better to bathe the burn given by the metal table in the sun.) The coating, more like fish & chip batter than traditional Southern style, holds onto hot oil like a sponge. Remember TV dinner fried chicken?  Even the fries left a thick coating on the roof of my mouth...thank goodness the side order filled an entire box by itself ;}\n \nThey've got one of the weirdest items I think I've ever eaten: a fried chicken liver salad sandwich. I read fried chicken liver sandwich at first before noticing the salad part. I kept thinking chicken liver salad, formed to a patty, and fried, like a crab cake. Couldn't wrap my head around it until I tasted it; the livers are fried, then made into a salad. Still heavy and weird; two bites were enough for me.\n\nIt's full on take away here...with only three tables and no inside seating. Everything, with exception to the lunch special, is ala carte. For the same $23, I could have feasted at Carver's, been entertained by the patrons and staff and had enough leftovers for dinner!",

                    "text": "I came here with a friend for Saturday lunch and was really pleased. Both regular and deluxe bento boxes also come with three california roll, two gyoza, two shumai, two vegetable tempura, a small salad, miso soup and white rice. Certainly filling enough for lunch and everything was delicious. Miso was sweet and mild.\n\nMy friend chose a \"flaming wok\" lunch special ($17) with kung pao chicken, hot and sour soup, white rice, two crab rangoon and a small salad. I tasted both the kung pao and crab rangoon and they were very good. The hot and sour soup wasn't bad at all, but it wasn't exactly \"hot\" or \"sour\", and instead a bit milder and plainer than I expected - this was the only item I thought was somewhat lacking. I haven't had crab rangoon in a really long time and was really excited with this one. We each had a soda for $2.50 each.\n\nThe place was clean and bright. Probably better for lunch than dinner in my opinion. Music was fine (boring but fine). Bathrooms were clean and far from dining tables which was nice. Location isn't the best, but if you are in the area, or live in any of the nearby apartment/loft buildings this is worth checking out for sure.",

                    "text": "This place offers up casual service of the sun-drenched flavors of the SE Mediterranean. Even though you are probably not too safe in Beirut or some of the the surrounding cities anymore, you are certainly safe at this Jerusalem.  : )    Walk right past the construction barriers on 5th Ave (circa March 2012) and you are there.\n\nThe trifecta of SE Med flavors for me are Hummus, Baba Ghanoug, and either Falafel or Kibbeh. So I had a Kibbeh platter with the previous two items and the yogurt/cucumber \"dip\" was supplied with the Kibbeh balls.\nThe Kibbeh balls were not greasy and had perfect texture and flavor. The lamb came through, but it's gaminess was not overpowering. \nThe chunky cucumber was perfect with the Kibbeh. And you could dip it or just eat it. I did both.  : )\nThe Baba was spot on, and perhaps a little more garlic laden than the norm. Fine by me. The roasted garlic and eggplant flavors were turning my pale Anglo Saxon skin an olive brown. lol  \nThe Hummus was creamy and perfect. It was thin enough to dip but still thick enough to control without spilling it all over. This is a hard thing to get right, so I appreciate it.  \nThe only things I could critique here are the thinish and served-cold pita, and the use of Frank's Red Hot as a hot sauce.                     "text": "Over the past few years Diddy Riese has been making some tweaks to their menu. Of course they have maintained their staples of cookies and ice cream, but they have recently added ice cream sundaes and Hawaiian shaved ice. They have also gotten rid of hot dogs, which they had for many years. Although the hot dogs were cheap, like everything else on their menu, I could never bring myself to try one.                     "text": "I've lived in a couple other apartments in Palo Alto, both near downtown, tiny and overpriced with none of the amenities that you can get at Stanford West. My last apartment was an old jr. 1 bedroom (more like a studio) with no parking and a kitchen just like Harry Potter's room (seriously it was tiny and built under the stairs). The person renting there is now paying $1800 (sucker!). With the way rent is going in this town, SW's rates are competitive for its location and what you can get for your money.\n\nFirst, you need to meet the eligibility requirements. Those that work at Stanford University get priority, then the Stanford hospitals, then others. But once you get an apartment it's pretty sweet. Living 5 minutes from work is awesome!\n\nI have a 2 bedroom split floor plan. The master has an en-suite bathroom, walk-in closet and it's own heater/air conditioner unit. The living/dining area is average size, and works for my small family. My kitchen has been upgraded with granite counters and has a nice sized pantry for storage. My son's room only has a heater - would be nice if it had air conditioning. His bathroom is separate. The unit comes with a full size washer and dryer. Living on the ground floor allows me to have a nice sized patio with space for a patio set and BBQ. I was lucky enough to get an apartment with an attached garage. Most units have separate garages - but hey that's better than the majority of apartments in PA!\n\nAnother major plus is that pets are allowed. Very few apartments take pets around here. Pet rent is $25/month and there's a $1000 pet deposit. There are tons of paths to walk your dog and even waste bag stations to clean up after it.\n\nOther amenities include: 2 heated pools and spas, a modern fitness room with Stanford wifi, BBQ area, playground, a convenience store, a car wash area, free car vacuum and a Marguerite stop. Too lazy to take your trash to the dumpster? Leave the bin outside your door and valet trash will pick it up at night. I always see security walking around so I feel safe. It does get noisy during the day with landscaping, deliveries, etc.\n\nCheck it out, it's great living here.",

I'm sure the hot sauce was pretty much the only flavor...and I don't mind that, just that I wouldn't taste much else. The chicken was a butterflied breast that was ridiculously dry. It's ok, hot sauce saves everything. \n\nThe good part of my brunch was the Irish breakfast. My gf didn't get what was happening here 'cause she thought the potato cake was \"just ok\". I really liked it, though. It was a little sweet, had a good onion-y taste and was fluffy and soft--kinda like someone took good mashed potatoes and fried it in a cake. I also loved every egg that we had, which were two poached eggs and a sunny-side up. They were cooked perfectly. I would definitely get something with egg again. The portabella looked like crap, honestly, but it tasted great. \n\nThe beer was indeed kinda expensive, but there are good, cheap options, too.",

The pastrami and corned beed had no fat, no taste, no flavor, a strange texture, and a peculiar color.  It looked more like shaved, pressed ham - like the discounted \"Buddig\" brand you got if you were a poor kid... that your mother tried to pass off as deli meat.  But at least that had some flavor.  The pale color of the meat and lack of taste suggested it had been boiled to death... prior to nuking it.  Yes nuked.  I should have known when I saw them put the meat in the microwave... that I was in for a not so pleasant experience.  I am not that poor kid anymore.  If I drop $15 bucks for a sandwich at Canter's I don't mind because I am satisfied with the quality and taste... it's worth it.  At Gandolfo's for 11 bucks... this is a ripoff.                     "text": "Whadalya have?!\n\nThe answer is, always, a chilidog, onion rings, a fried peach pie, and a frosted orange. It ain't that hard, folks. Their menu isn't that big. Nevertheless, it's common to greet \"Whadalya have?!\" with \"Uh....uh.....huh?\"\n\n\"Whadalya have?!\"\n\n\"Uh, I'm thinking......well, maybe.....\"\n\n\"Whadalya have?!\"\n\n\"Please.....for the love of God, I don't know! The thinking part in my head is hurting!\"\n\n\"Whadalya have?!\"\n\n\"Please don't yell at me.\" (Sob!)\n\nThe venerable Varsity, target of much love and much derision. Honestly, I don't know how much of both it deserves. It does earn some respect just for being a constant in ever-changing Atlanta. It's grown some, added a little bit of technology here and there, but for the most part, it's remained refreshingly old-school. Some might call it \"predictable,\" but I think most of those people expect too much for too little. It's a drive-in, people. They serve chili dogs.\n\nBut then how ARE the chili dogs?  Aye, and that's the rub. They're not very good, even by chili dog standards. OK, they're not Checker's quality (which, to me, is the culinary equivalent of getting a thousand paper cuts on the head of your penis), but I've had much better chili dogs in my day. They're still better than the hamburgers, so I still stick with them.  Comparatively their onion rings, greasy though they may be, score much higher in my book. And the frosted orange (the original Orange Julius before Julius found it) truly deserves its place in Atlanta lore as does any fried pie. \n\nReally, though, to most the food is secondary to the experience--the experience of being an original old-school Atlanta institution filled with hustle, bustle and aged engineers re-experiencing their days of youth. Seen through the prism of nostalgia, The Varsity comports itself well. Taken as a restaurant in and of itself, not so much.  To me, that's the crux of the polarized opinions surrounding the Varsity. I understand both views and that's why I sit solidly at 2.5 stars. For the sake of Yelp and sentimentality (even though I never attended GA Tech), I'll round up to 3 stars.",

                    "text": "Frankly, I had low expectations for a place that claimed to serve healthy-ish and tasty korean food in Westwood (aka not K-town). I almost expected it to be as frightening as the dim sum place that had previously occupied that space, but I was pleasantly surprised when I found instead a clean restaurant with welcoming, well-dressed service and straighforward bibimbop.\n\n I don't have much experience with bibimbop but ordering it at Bibigo was simple enough. Basically you order your type of bowl, type of rice, type of meat, and type of sauce. Then you grab a seat (and your kimchi) in either the indoor seating at the back or the equally relaxing patio (with heat lamps if you're a weather-spoiled Socal-er like myself) until they bring your food out to you. Another plus, you don't have to bus your own -- they do that too. \n\nI had the hot stone bowl with bulgolgi, barley and white rice, and kohot sauce. It was flavorful, actually piping hot, and not too greasy or heavy. Even though I essentially ate a huge pot of rice, I didn't feel overwhelming full or disgustingly greasy (big plus for relatively fast food). \n\nGreat place if you're stuck on the westside and you're hit with a sudden korean food craving. Bibigo makes ordering as simple and quick as Chipotle but with restaurant-style service and guilt-less food. Only 1 star off because it's slightly on the pricey side at a little over $10 per bowl, but then again, I'm used to K-town prices for korean food.",

                    "text": "Living in the Boston area certainly makes trips to Atkins difficult, an issue that is all the more noticeable come the New England autumn. The fall rolls in as I type this review, and I want nothing more than to enjoy some hot cider and cider donuts as I write it. Alas, I've yet to visit Atkins this year.\n\nPart farm stand, part specialty grocery, Atkins Farms holds on firmly to the New England charms while offering a wide selection of products. From lunch items, fresh fruit and produce (in the Autumn, the apple selection is one of the most thorough I've ever seen), Confections (great fudge), and baked goods, Atkins will cater to any and every that venture through it's doors.\n\nThe aforementioned cider donuts are a signature item of Atkins, and they're a must try. To describe them is difficult - they're delicious, though, and every time I've shared them with individuals who have never been to Atkins they're always impressed.  \n\nIf you're a fudge junkie, they've a large selection in the store that ranges from traditional to adventurous. All are home made and richer than rich. When it comes to the things Atkins sells, you can tell quite a bit of pride and effort goes into their products.\n\nIn and of itself, a visit to Atkins is an experience that goes hand and hand with a New England Autumn. Even if one is driving from halfway across the state, couple a visit to Atkins with a day at local Pumpkin Farms.                     "text": "I don't have a Taiwanese mother, but I do have have a Taiwanese mother-in-law, if god forbid my wife and I ever did split, part of the settlement would have to include visitation and dining rights for me.                     "review_id": "vA7V8r2MeoZLXlWSlYTcoA",
                    "text": "I don't know if MoCMoC has been revamped recently or I just have weird taste, but this is definitely my favourite sushi place in Princeton. I've been in Princeton for three and half years and can honestly say I've tried every sushi restaurant on or near Nassau, and this place is great.\n\nWhen I first sit down, I'm always provided with a hot disposable handtowel. I usually ask for hot water to drink, and that comes with another glass bottle for refills which they fill whenever it's low. The same refill bottle is available if you order tea.\n\nI'm a large fan of their tuna and salmon rolls and sashimi. I'm a picky eater so the variety I try there is pretty limited, but their sashimi is fresh and delicious, and their spicy rolls are not over-mayonnaised or overly spicy.\n\nThe dishware is beautiful, and the food servings are always tastefully arranged. The menu also pretty much has all kinds of common Japanese food, and since the other great Sushi place in Princeton (Ajihei) went sushi/sashimi-only, this is a good place to take someone who's not as comfortable with the idea of eating all fish for a meal.\n\nThe atmosphere is warm and quiet, the staff is very friendly. They might get a bit full on Friday and Saturday nights, but usually you're seated immediately.                     "text": "I figured I would wait to post my review until it started to get a little chilly out. Maybe the colder weather will be keeping people inside more and that will mean more time to get a new pet transitioned into your home *hint *hint* \n\nYears ago I adopted a kitten from here. Little black kitten.. the feistiest one of the bunch :) Well, it's been about 6yrs, she's still fiesty, a fan of cuddles, and also a very solid member of our family. When we got her she had an upper respiratory issue, just something that happens once in awhile. Figure she was found with her little family outside so she didn't get the best start. The shelter offered to take her back, but even after just a couple days we were in love with her. The staff sent us home with helpful instructions, things to help feed her and medicine.. all free. She got better fairly fast and today is healthy, strong and can pretty much climb walls. Our vets wall still carries her nail marks today from when she tried to reach an impossibly high window! \n\nThat winter we also got Sophie as a companion for Edie. While the two didn't end up hanging out as much as I'd have liked, they always sleep together and always have each others backs when another cat creeps into our yard. Even tho the local cats just come to bake on the walkway when it's sunny out and aren't looking for any Edie or Sophie trouble. Nice to know the yard has four-legged security!  \n\nMy last visit to the shelter wasn't such a happy one. One of my dogs had passed away and I brought him over to be cremated after my vet told me that was there they sent animals. I chose a private cremation so that I could have the remains back. It was a difficult time for me but the staff was very sensitive and helpful.\n\nDuring that last visit I took a walk through where they keep the cats. Most were keeping it cool and relaxing, some were ready to play catch the finger through the cage. Some wanted to be pet and then pet some more. \n\nI then visited where the dogs were. Almost every dog perked up, most coming to the front of their little areas. Excited to see someone, tails wagging, tongues hanging out making that one track mind face that shows thoughts of \"pet me, pet me\" \"let's play\" or \"ooh ooh a visitor\". \n\nAs I walked out of the room, heads went to the floor, backs turned to the room so they could look out their windows and some just curled up looking a bit spent or perhaps let down. It was genuinely sad.\n\nIf you have the space, some extra time, and love to give that's pretty much all the animals here are looking for. Well that and maybe a treat or two and some room next to you so that they can be close to someone that loves them :)",

            {
                "_type": "review",
                "_source": {
                    "votes": {
                        "funny": 0,
                        "useful": 6,
                        "cool": 2
                    },
                    "user_id": "ZH-OEKC-dOGQszEnXLpXnw",
                    "review_id": "2qnXCEvmvH9_atbh5NwDgg",
                    "text": "Months ago I got an insider tip that Al's was expanding into Harvard Square, which I can get to on my lunch break. I was ecstatic. Al's State Street Cafe has been one of my favorite local lunch venues for a very long time, and not having one nearby has been one of the few frustrating things about working in Cambridge. After checking time and again, I finally saw it today. Al's Harvard Square Cafe has opened. \n\nIf you've ever been to Al's State Street, you already know what to expect, but for those of you who haven't, here you go: \n\nExpect some chaos. Al's is loud. There is a constant din of customers and employees loudly calling orders back and forth. When it is busy, it's hard to tell which customers are waiting to order, which have ordered and are waiting to pay, and which have paid and are waiting for their sandwiches. There aren't lines so much as there are nebulae of people slowly weaving their way through each other. The chaotic nature is the only thing that takes a star off for me, and even then just barely. \n\nThe sandwich menu is simultaneous elaborate and simple. While there is a large selection of cold and hot subs, with many options for mixing and matching ingredients, you don't have to worry at all about price. Larges (which live up to their name) cost $7.50, and smalls $5.50, made with fresh ingredients and bread baked in-house. The prices are the same no matter what you order or how many (or few) ingredients you ask them to stuff into that delicious pocket of crusty bread. \n\nAs for the sandwiches, there isn't anything I've ever tried at an Al's that I didn't like. The eggplant parm, the chicken pesto, the cafe special (prosciutto, mozzarella, tomatoes and basil) and the lady cafe special (the cafe special without the prosciutto) have always been standouts for me. The lady I got for lunch today was as good, if not better, than ones I've had on State Street, and the scent wafting from eggplant parm I got for dinner had my mouth watering, too. \n\nOne thing that may be confusing and add to the chaos early on is the layout. They take orders for cold subs and assemble them on the left side, while taking orders for the hot subs on the left. However, the giant overhead menu has the hot subs on the left and the cold on the right. In the short time I was inside, I saw several customers confused by that, and I hope they switch them around. \n\nThe new location is in the Holyoke Center in Harvard Square. If you aren't looking for it, you may not find it, as it isn't visible from the street. I'm hoping this doesn't hurt the Cafe's ability to survive in Cambridge, because I plan to go here all the time. Thank you Al, for bringing your delicious subs up closer to my neck of the woods!",

                "_type": "review",

                        "funny": 0,

                    "user_id": "aRK5gNo8nrHWx0lQwwDlog",
                    "review_id": "WQI93W0EHKOvQyj0UJHgMQ",
                    "text": "I went in for the scorpion burger but unfortunately they were out of tempeh since the move to their new location -- next door! (I opted for tempeh cause I bought it once before at TJ's and it wasn't horrible.)\n\nSince they were out of tempeh, Alanna behind the counter kindly suggested the Super Italian Meatball Sub ($7.95). (side note: she's great.) I was hesitant to try their seitan sausage meatballs at first. At first glance, you could easily mispronounce it Satan. And the words dry, chalky, and artificial came to mind. \n\nBooooooy-ho-hoy was I wrong. (insert eye roll here.) \n\nThe hot sub was all toasty and buttered up like... I dunno, a hot buttery french roll. Four good sized seitan meatballs lavished in caramelized onions and roasted sweet peppers, finished off with ribbons of fresh parsley. If you married the standard sausage meatball with a Japanese potato croquette, and crumbled in a few chunks of soft breadcrumb for luck, these seitan meatballs would be the baby. I felt like the ramen girl bobbing for ramen as I was taking bite after bite. The spread of pumpkin seed pesto and homemade vegan ranch dressing, mixed with the Italian of all Italian seasonings had me at a loss of words. Can I please please please learn the culinary art of vegan cuisine, too?\n\nI also ordered the Lavender Lemonade ($2.50).                     "text": "A total miniature dive lunch counter surrounded by huge MIT-owned, pharma-rented buildings!  Very friendly owner and helpers from Senegal.  No seating, bring it back to your place of business or eat outside if it's nice out.  \n\nBreakfast until some reasonable hour (10am?), standard breakfast wraps and such- I haven't tried it yet.  \n\nFor lunch, ignore the big board on the back wall and look at the hand-written daily menu.  They usually always have beef shawarma and falafel wraps, but the Senegalese hot dish of the day changes- sometimes it's the Yassa other posters mentioned, sometimes a different stew or curry.\n\nBy the way, the ubiquitous tomato-and-cucumber salad or \"chutney\" everyone refers to is called \"fatouche\" or \"fattoush\"...  It is often served over lettuce and toasted flatbread, with certain herbs and sometimes onions.  A classic Middle Eastern or North African dish.\n\nDrinks selection is limited but they have basics such as Coke, Sprite, and chocolate milk.  Chips and dessert selection also limited.  But who cares, the real reason you come here is the warm & tasty main dish or wrap!\n\nTotally fair prices on the wraps, which are huge, and cheaper than nearby gourmet sandwich joints.                     "text": "So because I'm from California, I never got the whole bagel phenomena. Bagels are circular bread but...doughy-er. No big deal, right?\n\nWell, I've seen the light. Bagels are now more like magic to me than food, and Absolute Bagels is single-handedly responsible for my enlightenment. \n\nThe bagels are just so crusty and fluffy and hot and crust and yummy and--did I mention the crust is delicious? They have a ton of bagel varieties (my favorite is the whole wheat sesame) and an impressive assortment of cream cheese. The dutch apple cream cheese is so rich; it's really like eating pie innards on a bagel. The walnut raisin is also sweet and delicious. I am, however, partial to tofu cream cheese and Absolute has more varieties than any place I've been. Get the herb tofu! \n\nThe people who work there are really nice too. They know the regulars and are friendly to everybody. Plus they make a mean raspberry iced tea. \n\nThere are only two downsides to Absolute: the coffee is pitifully bad--so bad you might ask yourself, is this coffee that they gave me, or brackish water?--and it can be hard to get a seat if you want to eat there.                     "text": "This little bodega is anything but giant, but still provides much pizzazz for my kitchen. \n\nWhere else could one procure:\ncactus paddles\nTing (Jamaican grapefruit soda, basically a better version of Fresca)\nAdobo seasoning\nfrozen pupusas\nwhole coconuts\nAbuelita Mexican hot chocolate\nbags of habaneros\nmoist sponge cake\n... all in one place for pennies?\n\nShould it bother me that there's a layer of dust on everything and that I have to check expiration dates (which I definitely ignore)?                     "text": "My boyfriend and I probably frequent \"The Border\" more than any other restaurant in the Cambridge/Somerville area.\n\nAside from the fact that when I leave Border Cafe, all of my clothes smell of deep fried everything and Cajun spice, I love going there.  It has a fun atmosphere, it's cheap, and the food is great.  I know it's a chain, but that's probably why it's so good.  Consistency, my friend.\n\nThe tortilla chips are made fresh in-house, and are still warm/hot when they get to your table.  They aren't too salty, and can be dangerous, because when your basket is empty, the bussers bring you another full one, and another...and another.\n\nThe margaritas are fabulous.  One turns into three pretty easily, but the house margarita is so cheap, you should have at least three anyway.\n\nMy favorite meals are the Blackened Catfish Fajitas, any of the fried catfish dishes, and surprisingly, the Eggplant Royale.  I love Cajun/Creole food, and that's what I go to the Border for.                     "text": "The Frozen Custard, known as \"The Custard\" by locals, is a Lafayette institution. Generations of residents have made a trip to The Custard as a rite of passage, a first date, or just to hang out. Located on the corner of Wallace and Main Sts. across the street from Columbian Park, it's easy to see how this walk-up ice cream stand has become a local gathering spot. Many stories abound about \"Granny,\" an elderly lady and matriarch of the owner's family who could be found at the cone window every summer until her death. She plays a major role in a local legend involving Axl Rose, Guns n Roses lead singer and Lafayette native. Besides custard ice cream, other local favorites include fruit drink and nut bars. Hot dogs, sandwiches, and other food items are also served there. Recently, the custard machines were replaced and some aficianados believe the consistency of the custard is not what it used to be.                     "text": "Five Guys must be getting business in California from out-of-state transplants... it seems like they get a lot of backlash from In-N-Out devotees. The meat patty was good, bacon OK, but the bun was awwwwwful!  They wrap their burgers in foil and it makes the buns all mushy from the steam. For me, there's few things worse than a wet, mushy hamburger bun.\n\nThe cajun fries were OK.  Nice flavor, although I prefer shoestring.  I would be open to coming back just because Five Guys is right there in Westwood Village... maybe try out more of their menu like the hot dogs.  But I can't say I'm in love with their hamburgers...For this type of burger, you're better off going to Hole in the Wall or even the Stand.  I'd honestly rather have a Big Mac, or even a McDouble...",

                    "text": "Perks takes their coffee very seriously. Whenever I need a strong brew to keep me going after long nights of studying, I get my coffee here.                     "text": "The thing about TC is that it's cheap food that tastes excellent for its cost.                     "text": "Whenever the situation warrants, I'll usually ask a business acquaintance from the Pittsburgh area whether they have been to \"The O\" lately.  Usually I get a smile and a conversation ice-breaker.  It's been years since I've been here, but by all indications, little changes.  In Pittsburgh's Oakland neighborhood, the heart of the college district, \"The O\" represents all of the angst and energy, the culinary hedonism and \"WTF\" attitude of my undergraduate years (in Cleveland).  Hot dogs are their namesake, and they're alright; the burgers and steak sandwiches are okay.  What everybody remembers about \"The O\" must be seen to be believed.  An order of fries or onion rings is huge beyond anticipation.  I would suspect that a few orders of fries from \"The O\" would have carried Napoleon's troops across Russia in the middle of winter.  Quantity aside, they're good.  You won't find the crisp, double-fried french fries or duck fat and truffle froufrou here; this is a roll-up-the-sleeves blue collar place.  I doubt that it is the cleanest place I've ever eaten in, but this isn't a place for whining and complaining, calorie-counting or sustaining a healthy diet.  It's cash-only, and there's no parking for blocks around, but that would be whining and complaining.  Order, sit down and gorge; eating can be this simple!",

The music is loud and often upbeat, even when it's empty, which isn't very enjoyable.\n\nI have to say, I don't think it's really hard to make diner food vegetarian-- meat substitutes are everywhere (and this place makes full use of them), and dairy and eggs are the basis of diner food. But it's hard to make diner food interesting without the cheese and eggs. I wish there were better vegan options-- the \"Fakin\" faux bacon is just frozen Morningstar Farms pink smokey-flavored cardboard instead of something higher quality like tempeh bacon; bring back the marinara sauce for the zucchini sticks; the lack of vegan hot fudge is just disappointing-- and slightly lower prices.\n\nI especially wish there were some decadent vegan desserts.                     "text": "I really wanted to like this place... and perhaps someday I will be back, but it won't be for a very long time.  Not until they've worked out a lot of issues.\n\nI can appreciate that during a soft opening, which is when our party of 7 attended, there will be glitches and I was by no means expecting a flawless service; however, the brazenly casual attitude of some of the wait staff paired with a 2.5 hour dinner service (not by our choice) cannot be justified.\n\nCLIFF NOTES VERSION OF MY REVIEW:\n- Who brings a bottle of wine to a table already uncorked and places it on the table with wine glasses and walks away?  No approval tasting, no pouring done whatsoever.  That's a first! \n\n- Cambodian style doesn't mean bringing out dishes 1 by 1 and expecting a family style meal to take place when portions are clearly individual and it's just not possible to share a single order of 4 fresh springs among 7 people - it just doesn't work.\n\n- My soon to be sister in law is Cambodian - so please don't disrespect her by telling her that this is traditional Cambodian style of service.  Just be honest - tell us that service is slower than optimal as you are still adjusting to having a larger restaurant with new wait staff.\n\n\nFULL REVIEW: \n\nWhen our party of 7 arrived at 7pm on a Saturday evening, the restaurant was about half-full.  We were given 2 or 3 menus to start with as the restaurant was running short on menus.  That wasn't a problem as within a few minutes time, more menus freed up.  We placed our drinks order & food order and chatted away while enjoying the ambiance of the restaurant (which is quite clean, nicely lit and overall comfortable).\n\nThis is when things started to go downhill.  Drinks started arriving one-by-one spaced out quite unevenly and we had to remind our waitress that some of us were still missing drinks.  My brother's fianc\u00e9e and I ordered a bottle of Kenwood Merlot to share - the bottle was placed on the table, already uncorked, accompanied by two wine glasses.  Our wine was not opened in front of us, we were not poured a taste nor were we even poured our wine.  It was just all put down in front of us.  First time that's ever happened to me in a restaurant.  Never mind the fact that the wine was not very good - it seemed watered down in taste, very light-bodied.  Not what I'm used to in a Merlot.\n\nNext, 1 of our 2 appetizers of Fresh Spring Rolls arrived.  A single order has 4 pieces, mind you we are a party of 7 so we were expecting the second order to come out simultaneously (or at least within close proximity).  After waiting for 5-10 minutes, we questioned our waitress on the status of our second plate of rolls and were told that this restaurant provides Cambodian Family Style service - so plates are meant to be shared and food is brought out one at a time as it is ready.  Seriously?  We are supposed to share 4 rolls between 7 of us then get another 4 rolls to share again?  How does this logic make any sense?\n\nEven the soups we ordered for appetizers came out at a staggered pace.  My friend finished his before mine was even brought to the table.  That said, the Shrimp Tom Yum soup and Chicken Lemon Soup were both quite tasty and well executed.\n\nFinally, our entr\u00e9es - there was a good 30 minutes time difference between the arrival of our first and last entr\u00e9e.  We also had to remind our waitress for the rice bowls that were supposed to accompany our dishes.  Given the size of the plates and the individual portions of rice doled out, I do not consider these really family style and my brother's fianc\u00e9e, who is Cambodian, agreed.  Again, the food itself was delicious - we ordered Loc Lac, Cha Ugg (which resembled a plate of Alpo dog food but tasted much better than it looked thankfully), Cha Krung (tasty) and Chicken Fried Rice (for those less adventurous in our party).\n\nAlthough we wanted dessert, 2.5 hours had lapsed since we were first seated and the thought of waiting another hour for our dessert did not sit well with us.  I will commend the staff for allowing myself, my brother and his fianc\u00e9e the opportunity to visit the kitchen and speak to the Chef.  As my soon to be sister-in-law mentioned to the Chef, the food is good and we understand that things are busy, but the suboptimal service is what we found inexcusable.\n\nI'd like to give Floating Rock another shot... after my trauma has subsided and after they've worked out their kinks.",

I think they dissolved some bouillon cubes in some hot water and served them as miso, regular, and a third variety that I'm blanking on at the moment (perhaps because the memorable flavor was ... salt!).\n\nThat ought to be enough to put you off this place.  But in case you still think Shabu Square might have some redeeming qualities that could merit checking it out in person, please allow me to further disabuse you of that sadly mistaken idea.                     "text": "Toscsi's has been entering my bloodstream since 1984, when Gus and his brother Joe (now of Rancatore's fame) were often behind the counter. Now Gus and sister Mimi run the place. Tosci's has THE best ice cream selection in Cambridge. Quality is outstanding, too -- on par with (if not slightly better than) Christina's and Lizzy's, if you're comparing it to local non-chain establishments. But Tosci's always has incredible, creative variety.\n\nNot only does Tosci's have ample seating, but the seats (very heavy metal chairs and couches) were actually made by former Tosci's employee and local craftsman Adam Simha!\n\nSo why on earth am I giving Tosci's only 4 stars and not 5? Because it's really, really expensive. For the portion size (pretty small), Tosci's is the most expensive ice cream around, by far. It's a shame, because I'd go there far more often, like I used to, if they were still more reasonably priced. But hey, it's a treat, and you get what you pay for!                     "user_id": "tGT0pwzr1PX192PrBv9e8A",
                    "review_id": "xPPDpjMfNwjweNR8WLmeOg",
                    "text": "On my mission to sample to delicacies of Troy, NY, I stopped by \"The Placid Baker\" today after noticing this bakery on a weekend stroll.\n\n\"The Placid Baker\" is an artisan bakery nestled in downtown Troy near Tosca and the now (apparently) defunct Illium cafe. According to their little menu, this bakery tries to use as much organic and local produce as possible.\n\nUpon entering the bakery, I noticed that the decor was simple, but gave of a great air of being natural and homey; the open air and natural lighting added to this ambiance. There isn't too much seating, but that shouldn't be too much of a problem given the nature of the area. The woman behind the counter was somewhat shy, but she was helpful and nice.\n\nThe pastries in the display cases look fresh and tasty - I wouldn't mind coming here again to sample a few of them. The prices are fair, running between $1.50 to $3 per pastry. The sandwich and bread selection available were written in chalk on the wall you face once you enter the bakery. The only thing I would improve regarding this display menu was writing down what beverages the bakery had available, as well as their respective prices. I thought they had a modest selection on their menu which compared well with their size and client\u00e8le.\n\nI ordered a Cubano sandwich ($5.50): Niman Ranch roasted pork, Black Forest Ham, swiss cheese, pickles, and whole grain mustard on a Ciabatta Roll. I had it heated on the panini grill, halved, and wrapped to go. When I got to my room, the sandwich was cool, but that's no surprise, I took a side-trip to a few other places.\n\nThe sandwich was very nicely wrapped in heavy brown paper. The sandwich was a medium sized portion, and half of it was more than enough to fill me up. I'm not particularly fond of pickles, so I took those out. They definitely didn't skimp on pickles though, the sandwich was artfully layered - they took two thin lengthwise slices of a pickle, halved them horizontally, and put them as one layer on the sandwich. \n\nOn the first bite of the sandwich, my first thought was, \"the Ciabatta is perfectly crusty on the outside, and soft on the inside.\" Next, \"GOD THIS SANDWICH IS SO GOOD.\" I like sandwiches, but I don't -love- them. I love this Cubano, even at a cool temperature, when I usually like my sandwiches hot. I could distinctively taste the ham and the pulled pork (the pork especially), and the nice tang of the mustard.\n\nI also had a cup of tea (16 fl. oz, $2.00, although their menu states $1.75) with my sandwich. They feature Divinitea Premium Organic & Biodynamic teas, and they had three available today - Ceylon Green Tea, Irish Breakfast, and some other I can't recall. I had the Irish Breakfast, and was pleasantly surprised to find out that it was looseleaf tea that was steeped using a small satchel held in place on the edge of the cup. The temperature of the water was -perfect-, piping hot (black tea is supposed to be steeped with boiling water anyways).\n\nThe bakery had Sugar in the Raw, PureVia, and Blue Agave sweetener available. I wanted to try the Blue Agave, but they were out, so I went with the PureVia. I usually have my tea with some half-and-half, but I didn't see any milk selections so I just had my tea with sugar. Surprisingly, this tea is perfectly fine without any milk to smooth it out. It went over the palate well and didn't leave any rough, drying feeling behind.\n\nAs I left the bakery, the only thing that scared me was the clash of the wooden screen door closing.\n\nBar that, I'm definitely returning to \"The Placid Baker.\"",

The toppings were good and the flauta exterior crispy, but the chicken was pretty flavorless so we added a lot of salsa.\n\nNext, we had chorizo tacos which were excellent. The chorizo was perfect, spicy and crisp nestled in a fresh corn tortilla. Moving on to enchiladas verde which were kind of mediocre and suffered from similar problems as the flautas and remedied again with copious amounts of salsa verde.\n\nBeef torta was a little dry and would benefit from some beans or mayonesa/crema. Quesadillas - Chicken tinga was very good, mushroom and corn was meh. Bisteca a la mexican was excellent. Strips of chewy flavorful beef simmered in what was like a hot chunky pico de gallo. Beans and rice were throw away sides. Finally, horchata was also meh.\n\nYou are probably wondering how much all of this cost? $40 for flautas, 2 tacos, 2 quesadillas, 1 torta, 1 enchilada plate, 1 beef entree, and 2 horchatas.                     "text": "First of all, I'd like to say that I don't give out high ratings like this very often, being one to always try to take EVERYthing a business should be into consideration for what kind of traffic it's focusing towards.\n\n  The traffic focus here: One's inner child & sweet tooth.\n\n   Upon entering I was IMMEDIATELY swept away by both the bright colors of the place, the modern day dance music (and karaoke machine???) You're always looking up and around.\n\n  The candies & apples are finely decorated and placed, in my opinion very clever how they are so near the door but without being in your face. I loved the nostalgic puppets they have and sat and played with the ''Lambchop'' puppet. If I had a child, we would have had oodles of fun sitting there and talking about how I use to watch it back in the day .\n\n  The hot chocolate is out of this world, I'd even say great enough to try even in the summer! Hot, moderately thick and full of flavor I melted to! Even my husband was very impressed, and he tends to have a very selective perspective with businesses, so I thank the staff for making him laugh so and being so cheerful! They had pleasant humor that this world needs more with their businesses. Youthful, but professional which is JUST what more businesses need in this day in age to remind us what service REALLY is and should be.\n\n  I'd have to disagree with ANYone feeling that the service of the girls here is anything short of efficient, kind, and always with a customer-friendly and attentive drive out of the corner of their eye, even their age considering (teenage to young college females). There were multiple questions I had about the place here, and not once was I brushed off or ignored as they would pass by.                     "user_id": "WwbzYyuhcoIokxtgQn4Rqg",
                    "review_id": "sX9KzJU0ciipTZim4Mqn_Q",
                    "text": "One of the things that's always annoyed me about using Yelp as a litmus test when deciding to check out a new place, is that you really can't trust any reviews in a college area. \n\nThe vast majority of college kids suck at food reviews, because they're comparing Pizza Hut (FIVE STARS!) with other discriminating food choices like the box of Pop Tarts they bought at Walgreens and have been living off of during finals week*.\n\nAlternatively, you get whiny diatribes about how the service took FOUR MINUTES, meanwhile providing absolutely no details about the food.\n\nNeedless to say, I approached Longhorn Po Boy with much trepidation. AND LONGHORN PO BOY SLAPPED THAT TREPIDATION OUT OF MY MOUTH AND REPLACED IT WITH AN AWESOME Mediterranean burger; a moist beef wonderland dripping with tabbouleh and Tzatziki and Feta, rivaling the Mediterranean in its herculean size and girth**. Different AND amazingly good.\n\nAs mentioned in other reviews, there aren't any Po Boys on the menu. This is a Mediterranean / American grill fusion-ey lunch counter. It's also lunch counter goddamn-heaven.\n\nNot horribly hungry? They offer low-priced plates --many under $5-- some as simple as a plate of hummus, feta and olives with a side of pita bread. You can routinely feed two for around $12-$18.\n\nThe Gyros are HUGE and greasy and ingredients are all high-quality. They offer a ton of veggie options: two of my favorites are the Salmon sandwich with capers, and the \"Green Goblin\", a spinach wrap with avocado, jalapenos, hummus, spinach, tabbouleh and a few other green-colored odds-n-ends. \n\nTheir Falafel isn't the best I've ever had in the whole world ever ever ever, but it's by no means off-putting. I could easily see myself ordering it again sometime. It lacks a certain sour quality, even with pickles. This is probably due to their hot sauce being a homemade concoction that is great for those that love chili-style hot, but I personally prefer RedHot on Falafel...the lack of that sour/vinegar bite from RedHot is probably what's missing.\n\nThe fries vary from being forgettable to amazing. When I stop wanting to put ketchup on fries and eat them plain, that's a warning sign the fries are good.\n\nWith such a huge variety on the menu, and great breakfast options right next door at the co-owned Lava-Lava*** coffee shop (competent breakfast tacos --till 2pm on weekends!-- and decent smoothies.), this would probably be the place I spent most of my time if I were going to UT, and being right off Red River, it's a great stop if you work in the area and have a full lunch hour****\n\n\n\n* EG: The Spicy Pickle? Really?!?\n\n **ew!\n\n*** This is a typo --it's actually Lava *Java*-- but it sounds like something out of Mario Brothers so I'm leaving it.\n\n**** wait time can vary...I think most people have simply forgotten that a good lunch counter takes longer than the insta-food franchises out there. That said, if you come during a lunch rush, you're screwed.\n\n\n\nedit: closed? NoOOOoooOooooooOOOOo[/vadar]",

                    "text": "While the whole hot power yoga thing isn't really going to help me with my alignment or my arm balances, it certainly gets my heart rate up and helps with my breathing.  And the heat...well, it is undeniable how much it helps me sink deeper into some poses.  For me, these classes compliment the slower, more technical and complex vinyasa classes I take at other studios.  Learn the basics of each pose and the mind-body connection that defines yoga elsewhere, but come to Prana Power Yoga for a sweaty, athletic, butt-kicking workout.\n\nThe studio is a clean, open, and bright loft space with interesting light fixtures to gaze up at and new hardwood floor to ground into.  I had a hard time finding a focal point on any of the walls, which threw off some of my poses, but my balance was also hindered by the various limbs from other people waving around mere inches away from me.  Other reviewers are spot on when they talk about how crowded it is here!  I have been to a lot of other studios that get packed and they use the same sticker method to help line up mats with even space between them.  However, I have NEVER seen such little space between each mat and each row.  If there was a law for this type of thing, Prana would definitely be breaking it.  Tall person in front of you?  Watch out for their feet flying back towards your face during a fast-paced flow.  Trying to use a block for your half moon?  Good luck finding a place to put it down.                     "review_id": "mcNV9GTTQTAZwiyM2sPDbA",
                    "text": "I'm definitely not the first LA foodie to write about this increasingly popular new gastropub adjacent to the USC campus. The Lab has taken the Trojan Nation by storm, luring students away from the all-too-familiar 9-0 and 29th Street Caf\u00e9 by promising hungry and, truthfully, thirsty co-eds carefully thought-out and deliciously prepared offerings, an impressive selection of well-chosen beer and wine, and an attractive communal space to socialize and speculate. Think back to The Max from Saved by the Bell; this neon-hued, multi-functional burger joint was the \"it\" place for Zack Morris and his posse of big-haired, high-riding classmates to see and be seen while enjoying the best burgers and fries that the neighborhood around California High School had to offer. The Lab enjoys many of these same features - a hot crowd of extroverted and educated socialites, newly-minted favorites such as Grilled Salmon with Middle East Couscous, Artichoke Fritters and Beef Sliders, and a centralized location to tantalize even the students hailing from North University Park area. My recent visits have seen samplings of Seared Ahi Salad, Caprese Flatbread, Stir-Fried Shrimp and Eight-Grain Salad, accompanied by the likes of Nobilo Sauvignon Blanc, Trojan Blonde and Samuel Adams Seasonal Ale. All were surprisingly inventive, satisfying flavorful and modestly portioned for pub fare, and everything was pleasantly well priced for those of us on a limited, pathetically self-funded budget. However, in a battle of the educational eateries, The Lab takes the cake for two all-important reasons: drinks and \"discresh.\" The fact that you can drink your discretionary funds away with the Red Trolley Ale - all thanks to your USC student ID - is revolutionary enough to send The Max back to the 80's. Sorry, Zack, there's a new hangout in town, and while it doesn't have a jukebox, it's got something your all-of-seventeen years have yet to see: lots and lots of alcohol.",

                    "text": "Cafe Luna no doubt has THE best brunch in Cambridge. Everything is fresh including the corned beef hash, which is really difficult to order from a restaurant and have it not be out of a can. Waffles, pancakes, eggs Benedict, sausages, etc. you can't really go wrong. Luna has a solid sandwich & salad menu with really good lentil soup and chili. Wine and beer are sold here. Smoothies are good and the hot chocolate is hands down the best you will ever have! The pastries in the front case are really good, although they don't always look as appealing as they taste. \n\nThe reason I give Luna five stars is because of the spacey staff, wait time and lack of dinner options. The wait staff is really nice, but can be really spacey and take a while to fulfill simple requests. It's been the same way since the place opened. However, once you've been going there long enough, it just becomes part of the scene because the food outweighs everything. \n\nIt's also really difficult to just walk in during the weekend to enjoy a meal. Now you have to call in advanced for brunch and they have a 10 minute hold. I miss the quieter days, but I'm happy that the business is doing well. The only good dinner option is the pizza, which isn't served everyday. The lasagna is flavorless. And I think I've tried something else, but it was just as flavorless and therefore, not memorable. Oh, and they used to serve the best gellato that I've ever tasted (better than anything you'll find in the North End or elsewhere), but problems with the freezer case and the new design caused them to get rid of it. I wish they still sold it. \n\nCafe Luna = good for a scheduled brunch or laidback lunch.",
