                    "text": "NAME: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County\n\nTYPE OF PRODUCT OR SERVICE: Displaying natural history from prehistoric times to the present\n\nADDRESS: 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007\n\nPHONE: 213-763-DINO (3466)\n\nGENERAL LOCATION: Just north of the Coliseum in Exposition Park\n\nHOURS: M-F 9:30-5; St-Sn Holidays 10-5\n\nWEBSITE: http://www.nhm.org/\n\nREVIEW: When I was a kid old enough to ride a bike everywhere, I lived a little over a mile from the Museum. Many's the weekend I would spend packing a lunch on my spring-loaded bike rack, pedalling down to the Natural History Museum. I'd lock up my bike in the bike rack, and then spend the whole day wandering through the halls and soaking up all the knowledge there.\n\nPrehistoric animal skeletons, dioramas showing life in Los Angeles 35,000 years ago, jewels and polished rocks, models of planets -- oh, just all kinds of things that fascinated me! The building itself was a fascination. It was my private adventure. And while in the park I'd visit the Science Expo, the Armory, and the Sunken Rose Garden. \n\nTimes have changed since then. Then, a weekend meant light attendance, everything was peaceful, and everything was free. Instead of a McDonald's in the Science Expo building selling crap, there was the downstairs cafeteria in the Museum, with its wonderful murals, selling tasty hot food.\n\nNow, everything costs, and the park is filled with families having picnics and playing soccer. Very different from my time. But the Museum is still there, better than ever, and you need to go spend a day soaking it up!\n\nPAYMENT: Adults $9; Seniors (62+) $6.50; Kids 13-17 $6.50; Kids under 5 FREE\n\nPARKING SITUATION: Reasonably large pay lots",

                    "text": "After hearing about The Judge's Inn for some time now, I decided to try it for lunch.\n\nFirst off, the restaurant is beautiful, there is a nice little stage for live music, a game room with a pool table and darts, not to mention to beautiful ceiling- just look at it to glimpse Troy's golden days.  \n\nThis place takes the legal theme and runs with it.                     "text": "Brunch here is amazing. I've been here before for dinner and found service to be somewhat uneven (waiter walking away too quickly before you get to ask questions, water service not great, etc), but brunch... brunch is a special thing.\n\nIt is wonderfully quiet for brunch (possibly due to the price tag - $35/two courses - but it's worth it). The quiet let us have a chance to take in and enjoy the peace of the beautiful views by the window. There was classical music over a set of speakers, and I felt happier just being there. \n\n(Note for view-seekers - they will offer you the balcony seating outside, but they don't have umbrellas outside, which is tricky to accept in the hot summer sun. The views inside facing north are not quite as stunning as the views outside facing south, but they're pretty nice, and they'll also let you wander outside and explore the balcony after your meal if you wish.)\n\nBrunch service is attentive and every single detail of the food preparation is perfect. The formality here is *not* stuffy the way it can be at dinner - it's just nice.\n\nWaffles came out on lovely heated white plates, decorated with splashes of top-notch fruit (also warmed), and with maple syrup heated up as well.                     "text": "Perhaps the thing I miss the most about living in North Carolina is the abundance of biscuit/southern cooking eateries. And Sunrise Biscuit Kitchen is one of the places that I miss the most (followed closely by Bojangles and Biscuitville, of course). \n\nSunrise Biscuit Kitchen was always my artery-clogging food vendor of choice on Saturday or Sunday mornings/afternoons after a typical college weekend night of drinking and debauchery. Their biscuits always hit the spot, soaking up whatever liquor was still sloshing around in my empty stomach. They've got huge servings for a good price, so it's not a surprise that all my college friends, from UNC-CH, NCState, etc., loved this place. \n\nThe sweet tea was delicious. A little on the sweet side, but if you let it sit for a few minutes, the melted ice will water down the sugar and you will be left with the perfect level of sweetness. \n\nThey've got a pretty good selection on their menu, with most of the standard southern biscuit food fare, but I was always partial to their fried chicken biscuit combo (drink and hash brown side).                     "text": "The environment is warm with subtle lighting. There is plenty of seating around, so fairly big groups can gather together to eat. \n\nYou order at the register, take your number decal, and wait for your food. Because the dishes are made on the spot, it may take some time, especially if you order a meal that requires a good time to prepare, but once you are served your meal, you will soon find out it was worth the wait.\n\nAs the restaurant's name implies, your food is cooked to order, which is a big plus in my book.                     "text": "So, I spent some time searching for reviews of the Maryland Food Collective.  I searched and I searched, and unbelievably, I found nothing. I may be missing something... or UMCP needs to start representin' on Yelp.com!\n\nThe Maryland Food Collective is a godsend.  For the unacquainted, the UMCP campus is fairly massive with lots of places to eat but very few healthy options (in my opinion).  There are cafeterias located near student dorms, the Dairy, biznesses on Rte 1, and the corporate monsters in the student union (Sbarros, McD, Steak Escape, Taco Bell, etc...)  \n\nThe Maryland Food Collective (colloquially known as the Coop) is staffed and run by volunteer student workers.  They offer tons of vegetarian and vegan options.  They have a hot food line for lunch with 1-2 specialities (the plaintains are to die for).  They have a sandwich line where sandwiches are mto.  Falafel is often available.  My fave is the turkey salad with horseradish on a bagette.  They also have vegan turkey salad, vegan mayo, hummus, baba ganoush, etc...In the cold section, they have ready made burritos that are fresh and healthy from 95cents to around 2 bucks.  They have small cheese hunks, ranging from dill havarti to mushroom yogurt cheese (at least that was the selection today).  There's also an assortment of ready made sandwiches and local vegetarian/vegan foods from community establishments. In terms of snacks, they have granola, tons of dried fruits and nuts, wasabi peas...\n\nBfast: Fresh coffee, tea, with soy milk and raw sugar for you to add as you please.  Fresh bagels with a toaster oven, butter, cream cheese, soy butter.  \n\nWhat else?  There's too much to go through.  I love this place!  Hey, I've been here for 5 years already and hopefully 1 more before I'm out.  If it weren't for the Maryland Food Collective, I'd either be severely malnourished or totally obese.  Hurray, that I'm neither.  Yay for coops!",

                    "text": "A Cafe is a lone bright spot in an otherwise desolate strip of nothingness in the UWS.  Seriously, this area is the neighborhood that restaurants forgot.\n\nAt $20 and no corkage, their prix fixe dinner deal is unbeatable.  It's cheaper than cooking at home, and is certainly worth the priced paid.  Major points for the frugality and value for money.\n\nThe decor is eclectic to be charitable, and downright weird to be un-charitable.  It's cozy enough, but I made a comment that the decor was reminiscent of my stoner friend's dorm room in college.\n\nThe menu, like the decor, is also eclectic, with some questionable items.  An escargot starter with a garlic butter sauce, spiked with West Caribbean spices, had me sopping up every morsel of butter and snail juice with the complementary crusty rolls.  \n\nHowever, the scottish pheasant pate was more of a gratin and clumsily done.  Baked pears seem more of a dessert than a starter, and the grilled avocado, while I didn't try them, did not look appealing.  I couldn't fault my duck leg confit, but the accompanying cous cous seemed like an afterthought, and didn't bring much to the party. \n\nTo be fair, these guys are working under some serious restrictions.  An open air kitchen shares space with the dining room, and is about the size of a broom closet.  More impressively (or scarily), they lack a range, plancha or any flat cooking surface.  They do all the cooking with a salamander and a few small ovens, which severely limits the type of execution that they can achieve.  Unfortunately, this limitation resonates in their food, which is fairly clunky, heavy, and about as elegant as a NY Jet's Defensive lineman.   \n\nIt's obviously popular with the locals, as the place was packed on a weekday evening.  But would I travel all the way up to BFE UWS for some hot snail action?   Probably not.",

                    "text": "Urbana, IL has an embarrassment of good restaurants to choose from, and Xinh Xinh is high on the list. Both the hubster and I are quite fond of Vietnamese food and seek it our wherever we are, so we ate here twice during our 3 day stay. First, I really like the space, which, with its' corrugated metal walls and local art work, manages to be both urban and cozy at the same time. The guy at the counter waits tables, so he sat us, brought us water and served our food, all while taking care of other customers and running the counter very efficiently and with a smile. I had eaten a large lunch, so had the tofu summer rolls, which were great...very fresh veggies and marinated tofu, with a crunchy fried component in the center that added textural interest, served with a tasty hoisin-peanut sauce. When I looked around I noticed many other folks had ordered those tofu summer rolls, so they're very popular. I also ordered the chicken dumplings, which were excellent...tasty little fried morsels served with a sweet fish sauce dipping sauce. Doug had the bun (vermicelli rice noodle bowl) with chicken and an extra fried spring roll and said it was great...noodles a little thicker than the average that looked homemade and well marinated chicken, served with a sauce that he thought too sweet initially, but then warmed up to. Xinh Xinh has a wide range of beverages choices, from bubble teas to Vietnamese sodas, hot tea, an avocado shake, Thai iced tea, coconut juice, and that most delicious of beverages, Vietnamese drip coffee sweetened with condensed milk...rich and sweet yumminess. We had the banh mi on our second visit, which is the traditional Vietnamese baguette sandwich. We tried the roast pork pate combo and the pepper chicken, and they were both good, but not stellar. I admit to being a little spoiled by the banh mi at Dong Phuong in New Orleans, which have ruined the experience for me anywhere else. We didn't try the pho, as we don't eat beef and they don't offer the chicken variety, although they do have a vegetarian pho on the menu. I guess my favorite part of Indian cuisine is dipping naans into different sauces, and this place provides decent sauces for me to dip stuff in, so I'm happy. Fills you up really fast too. The gf couldn't finish her portion of the food, so we boxed it and it becomes her meal for the next day.\nI am not an expert on how Indian cuisine should be like, but being one of the two Indian restaurants in SLO, I think this place is doing alright. Then he went to the kitchen and ignored us for a bit when we are done deciding. I would be more okay with this if the place is really busy, but that was not that the case. The restaurant only had two more tables to take care of at that time and their service was not as good as it should be. The time it takes food to get to the table is also quite long for some reason.                     "text": "I admit (with shame) that I delayed eating at Doodles until just recently.  The location is set in the greasy pit of campus-town, where I hesitate to venture unless compelled to by some supernatural force (like the lure of hot noodles in winter).\n\nThe interior space of this tiny shop is not exactly comfortable, but this is the unfortunate case with most campus businesses (i.e., furniture and surfaces should be able to withstand physical punishment from college students).  For those choosing to dine inside, there's a picnic-style bench and a counter with stools.  I guess I can't hold the lack of interior design against them because the restaurant is not attempting to follow a conventional theme.  \n\nThe manager explained the primary concept behind the place is \"food-to-go\" (so students can eat something while running around campus), and all the food is packaged for such a purpose, including the noodles.  Next to the front counter is a cooler with various drinks (both American sodas and Asian fruit juices) and \"snack\" foods.  From what I observed, the same snack foods aren't served each day, though I haven't gone often enough to figure out the pattern/rotation of the different foods.  These were a few dishes I noticed during my visits: glutinous rice balls (classic snack served in Taiwan and other parts of China), Chinese steamed buns, edamame, various sushi rolls, vegetarian gyoza, and spam musubi (a Japanese-Hawaiian invention that probably deserves a certain skepticism from most diners). \n\nOf course, the main feature of this shop is ramen.  When I mention this, most people respond indignantly, \"What!?  You can buy ramen for 40 cents at Wal-Mart!\"  The ramen-eating experience here is NOT the same as boiling noodles and adding sauce packets in your own home, though.  Your ramen bowl is fully customizable, from the available broths (sesame, miso, kimchi, beef, seafood, etc.) to the toppings you can request for your bowl (baby bok choy, nappa, egg, fried tofu, wakame, Thai fish cakes, beef meatballs, etc.).  At around 50 cents per topping, I was initially expecting pretty skim offerings, but I actually get a pretty decent ratio of noodles to vegetables.\n\nMaybe this little restaurant appeals to me because very few places can offer me a reasonable lunch for $3 (and student debts are the primary constraint on my dining options).  Probably real adults with real jobs would be less impressed by Doodles, but this is an ideal restaurant for most college students.",

                    "text": "What a fabulous hotel!  I stayed here recently for a friend's wedding and was extremely pleased with my stay.  The decor is beautiful (in particular, I compared it with the Hyatt Santa Clara, where i also stayed recently, and which has much more dated decor), and their Heavenly beds are, yes, heavenly.  I normally hate hotel beds, but I slept like a baby at the Westin (though that could've been due to the copious number of gin and tonics I had at the wedding reception).  The rooms are sizeable, and the bathrooms are *amazing*.  The shower has dual heads, and the bathtub is detached, like some sort of class-ay master bath or what have you.  My only complaint (and reason for the one star deduction) was that it took about 10 minutes for the water in the shower to warm up to a suitable temperature.  However, my friends who stayed in a different room had no problem with their shower, so it was probably just the pipes in my room.\n\nThe pool area, as others have mentioned, is quite small, so don't expect to get your lap swimming in.  I didn't go for a dip, but my friends did enjoy the hot tub.                     "text": "I'm not the biggest fancy dinner person, but Flemmings is a great place if you want to go somewhere \"nice.\" The restaurant has all the fancy restaurant stuff to impress your girlfriend: hot plates, cold forks, choice of light or dark napkins, and chocolate lava cake. If you need somewhere to go for a special occasion, this is a good bet. It wasn't difficult to get a reservation even on Valentine's day. Note: Flemmings gives you a $25 gift card for coming on V-day. \n\nFill up on free bread because the entrees are pricey and everything comes Ala Carte. Meaning, that if you want the steak you have to pay $30 and then another $10 for mashed potatoes. Expect to spend some cash at a nice restaurant like this, but you don't need to break the bank. \n\nI would recommend going on Sunday and getting the Prime Rib Dinner for $36 because you get the Prime Rib, a salad, a side and a desert. That' a $60 value based on their prices. If you are trying to save some money another option is getting something off the \"petite\" part of the menu. I ordered the Petite Fillet Mignon and it was only $29 and it came with potatoes. That with the free bread (with yummy butter spreads) will get you full. \n\nI also hear that this place has a great happy hour between 5-7pm where you get fancy cocktails and appetizers for $5 or $6 each.                     "text": "This Best Buy is terrible.  I base this claim off of several observations.\n\n1. They never answer the phone. I presume this is because the answer to any question of the form \"Do you have xxxx in stock?\" is \"No.\"  This brings me to my second point.\n\n2. Their selection is mediocre at best.  Keep in mind, it's still a Best Buy, so they have a good deal of inventory, but as Best Buy's go it's not that big, and I would say at least 40% of the time they don't have the thing I am looking for.  Granted, during the holidays there were some hot commodities that would have been hard to come by regularly, but even prologue to that I had trouble finding what I wanted.\n\n3. People like to camp in the bathrooms.  No, wait, hear me out on this.  The men's bathroom has two stalls.  The one time I felt nature calling while in this Best Buy, I stepped into the men's room to find both stalls occupied.  Fine; I love the waiting game just as much as the next guy.  Except for the fact that one guy is clearly reading the newspaper, as evidenced by the ruffling of the pages, and the other guy stays on the pot for upwards of 15 minutes, only to finally stand up and retrieve his shirt from the ground, put it back on, and exit the stall.                     "text": "I was shopping in the Village on a cold and blustery day, and as I walked from store to store, I was gradually lured like Toucan Sam by the smell of fresh herbs and spices wafting from what I discovered was Miss Saigon Cafe, a small (about 10 tables) though smartly appointed little restaurant. I thought a steaming bowl of Pho would be just the ticket, but unfortunately, no dice that day. Not to be discouraged, I thought I'd go for one of my favorites, the Bun Thit Nuong. The menu however was completely in English - not that I speak Vietnamese or anything - but it kinda threw me off since I'm used to looking for a section of Bun dishes, or scanning for the delicious Thit Nuong, and without the Vietnamese alongside the English, you might be ordering something slightly different. Seeing a vermicelli section listed with pork, chicken, beef, and several other options, I figured that was what I was after, and ordered a combination  of pork and egg roll for $12. While the pork was savory, it wasn't particularly warm, and the noodles were actually quite cold. The egg roll was piping hot, and allowed me to make some warmer bites. The vegetables were very fresh, including lettuce, sprouts, cucumber, carrots, and mint. You don't get mint at a lot of places, and I found it gave a delightfully pungent aroma to the dish. Along with the fish sauce on the side, it all tasted good, I just wish it had come out a bit warmer on a cold day.\n\nA bit tired, and fond of Vietnamese coffee, I ordered a glass (why iced coffee on a cold day? I don't know.) It came out in a small glass mug as the coffee dripped into the condensed milk at the bottom. I poured it over the accompanying glass of ice, and while good, it wasn't $4.50 good. In the end, I left with a nearly $20 tab (tax incl.), and though it was good, it wasn't quite the weekday lunch I might have gotten elsewhere for the price. I'll probably continue to patronize Miss Saigon when I'm in the village, just hopefully on a Pho day.",

                    "text": "Finally getting around to writing a review of this place . . .\n\nI'd never had Ethiopian food before, so I don't know how this might compare to other places in terms of authenticity but I can tell you one thing, the food here is really good!\n\nI love the service here. The staff is friendly, and they even explain all of the dishes to you and how to eat them, so fear not if you've never had Ethiopian before. The waiters also bring around hot towels at the beginning and end so you can clean your hands before you eat . . . and after since you eat the meal with your hands. Regular utensils are available too for those of you who don't care to get down and dirty. Personally, I think eating with your hands makes the food taste much better.\n\nWhen you walk in, you can opt for conventional table seating, or the more traditional basket table seating. I think if you are going in a large group and sharing the buffet, the regular table seating may be easier to work with. However, the basket table is a pretty fun experience.\n\nWhenever I come here, I always order the same thing: the meat buffet. I love that there are so many dishes that come with it, and they are all you can eat. Don't let your eyes deceive you--it may not look like much, i.e. little mounds of food on a tray, but typically one or two refills of a few dishes will be enough to leave me happily full and satisfied.  The buffet is great in that you get to try a little bit of everything.\n\nMy favorite of the buffet dishes are the lamb and the mixed vegetables. I can't get enough of them. I also love the soft, white bread--happy, heavenly, starchy goodness.  \n\nI haven't tried any of the desserts here, but I have to admit, they all look really delicious. The problem is, I usually fill up with too much buffet and don't leave enough room for the after party.                     "text": "Oakland is full of lunch places, but if you are looking for something light, healthy, and fresh, you're pretty much out of luck....except for Eat Unique!  I had lunch here earlier today, and was so excited to see a menu of sandwiches and salads that didn't contain french fries....\n\nThe atmosphere is minimalist.  There are some bright colors, but it's mostly just cafeteria-style tables and chairs, no decoration.  You order at the counter, then wait awhile - about 15 minutes in our case - for your lunch.  My boyfriend got the meatloaf melt, and I ordered the grilled chicken pesto sandwich.  It was hard to wait so long, but as soon as we got our sandwiches it was obvious why we had been left hanging - the food was FRESH.  My sandwich was hot, the chicken fresh off the grill, the tomatoes sweet and flavorful, the pesto made in-house (you can see the rustic bits of pine nuts and basil, definitely not the jarred stuff), the ciabatta roll lightly toasted and crispy.  I was really impressed from the first bite.  There's nothing really unique about the sandwich, except that it is made with high-quality ingredients and hasn't been sitting in a case all day, but that made a huge difference!  I tried my boyfriend's meatloaf sandwich, which wasn't as big as I thought it would be, and I liked it okay...the sauce was pretty sweet.  I preferred mine - it tasted so garden fresh.\n\nFor dessert we had a black bean brownie - yes, really - and it was great!  Who knew?  It just tastes like a creamy, chocolatey brownie.  You can put black beans in dessert!?  This changes everything.  Definitely craveworthy.\n\nThe only thing I'm not crazy about is the ambiance.  Since you have to wait so long, it'd be nice if the dining area was more comfortable or better maintained.  There was lots of water on the floor and I almost slipped a few times, we had to wipe down our own table....not a huge deal, but we noticed.  There are lots of big, sunny windows, so that's a plus.                     "text": "Authentic is the first word which comes to mind.  Authentic in a world where authentic is masterfully recreated but seldom delivers on its promise.  CCB is a true gem.  \n\nMy friend and I spent the night in SLO during a trip to Hearst's castle. We created our own pub crawl and started at Central Coast because it was the closest bar to our hotel. Thus my head was still clear when I left CCB and this review is remarkably accurate.  \n\nWhat a find!\n\nThis is not a restaurant, there's no good food to order.  They do happen to have some really tasty snacks from Louisiana, but the showcases here are the beer, the ambiance and the beer.  Not into beer?  skip it, head downtown. \n\nCentral Coast has just made a major upgrade to their production capabilities.  When you taste their beer you know why they are in demand.  They make a variety of beers and ales so there is something for any beer lover.  They serve you in tasting glasses equivalent to 1/3 of a pint.  But each taste is only $1 or $2, so you end up drinking a fresh, deliciously crafted pint for $3-6.  Quite a deal for a pint of anything, let alone something the quality CCB is churning out.  \n\nThe staff are friendly and knowledgeable. Since the bartender is one of the 3 guys who actually makes the beer, he can basically tell you anything you'd want to know about the beer or the process by which it is made.  The bar (which has about 6 seats) is literally sitting in the middle of the industrial tubs they use to make the beer.  You are drinking smack in the middle of the brewery itself. Pretty neat.\n\nLooking for a high class place with hors de vours?  Not for you.\nLooking to impress your date with your worldliness?  The box of board games beside the bar will hurt your chances.\n\nLooking for a casual, laid back atmosphere where you can get the treat of delicious beer?  This is your spot. Drew, the bartender handed us the tv remote without us even asking.  The owner came over and told us the origins of India Pale Ale.  I sampled (not shot glass tastes, real samples) 5 beers for $8 and found 3 that I loved. We sampled the hot nuts- damn tasty, got our lips a burnin. \n\nOh, and my traveling companion found the perfect gift for her brother in law to be- a growler of their Winter Ale. \n\nGO HERE!  You will not regret it.",

                    "text": "I lived in a city full of restaurants and good eats (Houston), and my review of this place is not as severe as others.  I think the place is generally trying to make a good impression- a modern stove, exposed stone wall, contemporary seating.  I would not call it \"cuban\" or even \"latino\" per se, except it has a creative menu for mixed drinks. I had the \"desert healer\" because I am fan of gin, which is quite refreshing.  The chips/peach salsa sample was excellent to go with the type of drinks it served.  My friend and I shared the pressed watermelon salad, it has the right blend of sea salt, arugula, fluffed goat cheese to counteract the sweetness of the fruit, the combination is thoughtful and not overdone.  For main entree I had the corvina, in my opinion, is one of the better fish dish I have had in a long time. It is perfected seared with the right amount of spice, served over a savory serving of rice.  To top it off, I had the vanilla leche (which was a bit too hot off the frying pan) but otherwise a well rounded compliment to my dinner.  The quality of the food is good. I do not understand people who complain about the price- you are paying for creativity, ingredients and human labor, and why should things be cheap?!!  It is a bargain compare to restaurant this standard in Europe.  \n\nSeveral suggestions I have for the place- the seats opposite the booth on the left (of front door) are too low, it is awkward when you are facing people trying to have a conversation.  The music should be several decibel lower.  The general feeling of the place is too airy, too open, which is why normal conversation volume is strained.  The entree menu needs a bit more diversity from the rest of the main street venues, the restaurant needs its own niche, not \"just like the other down the road\" feel.  Pick one thing and do it REALLY well.  Even contempo mix can be bland after repetitions.  \n\nOverall, I would say, as someone who has a picky palate, the restaurant has potential and has room for improvement.  I would like to see it grow in its own personality and strength.",

                    "text": "My future mother-in-law was in town visiting me, and she wanted us to do a spa day so we could bond. She asked me to choose a place to get facials and massages. After reading countless reviews on Yelp, I decided to make an appointment here. I had already been here before, but for a full body massage.\n\nThere isn't much parking in the back or on the street but we were greeted in a friendly manner as we entered the spa. The young Chinese guy confirmed our reservation and then asked for us to pay for our services ahead of time. I told him we wanted to pay afterwards and he was fine with that. They make you fill out a sheet of paper with information, including an indication of where your pains are located.\n\nThis time I decided to try the $20 head to toe massage, where you are sitting in a chair with your feet in a bucket of soothing hot water, and you are being massaged fully clothed, from head to toe. For $20 you can't beat the price. They massage your head, neck, back, arms, legs, and feet all in one hour. The woman who was working on me was great, and pretty strong.                     "text": "It's important to have understanding friends who are unfazed by whatever you may ask them.  For example, when you happen to throw out something like: \"Hey, do you want to have a pancake breakfast at 8 am next Monday?\" you want someone to say \"Sure.\"  No judgments, no eye-rolling.  Just understanding and helpful suggestions - what more can you ask for?\n\nThat's how we ended at Kitchenette Uptown (not to be confused with this place, Kitchenette SF: http://www.yelp.com/biz/kitchenette-san-francisco#hrid:nUOY87bnI1ZJDU47n86nFQ).  It was my first time at Kitchenette since oh, about 5 years ago, so it felt new and exciting.  Actually, it felt kind of old and exciting, because that's the theme here.  It's easy to forget you're in New York City when you're dining at Kitchenette.  It feels as though you are transported to a small diner in the country (unlike a Cracker Barrel decor, this one feels more authentic).  The rustic and rusty sunflowers on the walls, along with simple white paint, make you feel comfy and homey.  The tabletops are made of old doors painted in soft pastel colors.  Ours were chartreuse and powder blue.  Ahhh, serenity now.\n\nThe food, fittingly, is simple comfort food.  I had scrambled eggs with  bacon, grits and multigrain toast.  Everything was above average, but not spectacular.  It's eggs and bacon, how original can they be?  I was pleasantly surprised by the grits, which were freshly made and tasted better than one would expect grits to taste north of the Mason-Dixon line.\n\nThere were only 3 other parties at the restaurant this early in the morning, and the waiter was on top of it.  He kept refiling our Mason jars with water, and kept offering us more coffee.  Eventually, we had no choice but to refuse his \"advances\" and continued our conversation sans coffee.  Finally, he brought us the check on a yellow tin tray: whaddya know?  more sunflowers.  2 big combo breakfasts + 2 coffees + tax = $27.  How can you beat that?\n\nBonus points for a great value.  Bonus points for serving coffee in big mugs, the way it's supposed to be.  More bonus points for air conditioning, as it was promising to be another hot day in New York City.\n\n***3.5 stars, rounded down***",

                    "text": "Growing up in the Midwest, any Chicago influenced cuisine is going to peak my interest and I had my eye on this eatery since their opening earlier this year. A break in the day allowed for an early dinner/snack, and what better time to have my first experience.\n\nUpon entering, the lack of any real pizzazz hits home hard. Yellow painted walls with only an open letter from the owner closest to the door, and a weak outline of the Chicago skyline are the only d\u00e9cor of ChiDogO's. With such a rich history, it should be a no-brainer to really pay tribute to one of America's great cities. The owner is a native Chicagoan, but doesn't provide any evidence of that, which is very disappointing.\n\nYou can hear the fry basket drop as well, as there is no music pumped in. This is an even greater travesty than the bare walls. Where are the sounds of Chicago bluesmen like  Buddy Guy, Howling Wolf, and Willie Dixon? Hell, even \"My Kind of Town\" by Frankie on repeat would at least be something.\n\nThe theme of the fast-casual eatery is Chicago style hot dogs, and Chicago Italian Beef Sandwiches. An Italian Beef Sandwich had been something I had been craving. A reasonable $ 0.50 add-on charge for Mozzarella and peppers is in place, but the sandwich would be naked without them. The size of the sandwich paired with the prize is reasonable. The trouble I had with it is that the meat tasted and looked like Arby's roast beef, and is more than likely purchased prepared and pre-seasoned, and not roasted in house. The size of the kitchen was more than adequate to roast several tip roasts. The bread and Au Jus were perfect however, and the fresh crispness of the Giardinera mix was right on point.\n\nThe fries were not fresh-cut, but were thick, crisp, and made for great clean-up of the left over Au Jus from the sandwich.\n\nThe service was very by the book, but solid. After I had sat down, the employee stated very sternly to a patron that a combo deal could not allow for a Chili-Cheese fry modification, as the system would not allow it. It's never good to see uneducated (about their product, not in general) robots in the food and hospitality arena, but such is life  It was a one-man show on a Wednesday afternoon, but the order preparation was fairly quick. \n\nI will return, but with a lesser amount of enthusiasm. It would be a pleasant surprise if the ownership group embraces the spirit of Chicago more though.",

                    "text": "Restaurants like this are rare, and for me to give a rating of 5 stars is even more rare.  Walking into this restaurant is fun, the design and colors used give it a laid back but respectable atmosphere.  It is a bit cramped and a touch on loud side in the bar, but that could have been the people in the bar.  We were sat in about 20 minutes, in the mean time the hostess got me a drink.  The mixed drinks were fantastic original, subtle and tasty.  I normally find that new drinks of late are over spiced too strong, too weak or just not mixed with things that mix. Who ever created the drinks at Hungry Mother knew what he/she was doing and should be hired by, Chez Henri, Temple bar, West Side Lounge, and Rendezvous\nWe sat at a table near in the bar. The waitress was attentive and fast, without being obtrusive. I started with the Tongue as a snack, most of you probably aren't interested in tongue but it was very good. Next I had the catfish.  I don't like catfish but the southerner I was with recommended I try it.  There was a crust on the fish which was perfect and added just the right amount of texture and spice.  I don't like catfish because of the muddy taste that it can have.  This fish had minimal but an occasional touch of the muddy flavor, but it worked.  It worked because of the Cajun style sauce that came with the dish, which was spicy but not hot, so that it really was very well balanced.  Collard greens and rice accompanied the dish as well. The collard greens were the best I have ever had, but then again my experience with collard greens is limited to the northeast.  The rice was excellent.  Then came the grits, which had fatty ham and cheese added, again excellent. Finally I was persuaded to try the chocolate cake, which was by far the best and most moist chocolate I ever had.  When I say moist its hard to describe but I guess I should say light and in no way like any cake I have ever tasted.  I met the owner, a surprisingly thin man for such an excellent restaurateur.  He was gracious, modest, and seemed somewhat surprised at my compliments. Please try this great restaurant and let me know if you rate it anything less the five stars.",

Hmmm, I'll hold off on that one.\n*No-powder flavors.  Unlike my other popcorn visit to a store down south, the popcorn did not taste like it was dipped in powder.                     "text": "I think we found our next favourite Chinese take away restaurant.\n\nThe decor, as others have mentioned, is nothing special--but clean and air conditioned--and the menu typical of what you'd find at any Americanized Chinese place.  \n\nWe stopped in for lunch yesterday because I was craving fried rice, and were pleasantly surprised to find that lunch specials were also served on Saturdays.\n\nImmediately after being seated, we were brought fresh, ice cold water, and fried wonton skins with duck sauce to munch on, which was appreciated because we were hungry.\n\nJim wanted something fried, so he ordered the 5-spice chicken with an egg roll, I went for Szechewan beef with fried rice and wonton soup.\n\nSoup: bright yellow with fresh scallions, thick skinned wontons.  Not bad flavour wise--the scallions helped--but the wontons were thick and chewy.  Jim got these.\n\nEgg roll: could have been better; a little bland\n\nThe chiles in oil---superb!  A lot of places have rancid or dead oil, but here it was fresh and hot!\n\nThen the giant plates of food.\n\n5-spice chicken: deep fried and tender, with a gooey sauce that wasn't too sweet--a bit tangy, but wow.  It was almost like a good barbeque sauce (yes, they actually do exist) instead of overly sweet to the point that you want to yak.  Very good, and I think I ate 1/3 of Jim's.\n\nSzechuwan beef: a generous amount tender strips with the typical melange of fresh veggies--Jim stole all of my broccoli, of which there was a lot--and the sauce was good and mild but not overpowering.  No MSG headache either.  \n\nIf we're going for dim sum, we will definitely head back to Shanghai Park, but for friendly service and a great no BS with tasty and fresh food, we'll head back to Hunan.\n\n$13 including tax for 2.  It's really a 3.5, but I felt like being generous\n\nEdit: I just browsed the other posts--somehow Princeton falls into the category of major cities in the world that should have a Chinatown?  LOL!  That's what you have Manhattan for sweetheart.  Or San Francisco, Paris, London...but Princeton?  That's cute.  We're in the suburbs.",

                    "text": "I can't say that this is going to be my favorite Thai spot, but we had the best service here tonight.  Our waitress was super fabulous, hilarious and very helpful.                     "text": "This has been on my list of places to checkout since I moved to Raleigh last year, and finally got my chance yesterday, and it lived up to the hype.\n\nWent here around 2pm on Saturday, place was fairly empty, and were able to snag a spot in the back instead of trying to find something off Franklin Street.  Grabbed a couple seats at the bar by the fermenting machines, I'm a real beer nerd, so I was perfectly happy with the atmosphere.   I went with someone who could be considered a \"regular\" so he gave me a breakdown on the difference between their regular and seasonal brews, decided to start with a seasonal.  Tried the 15th Anniversay, great light brew, liked it so much that I ended up picking up a growler to go.  Pretty great deal for a micro brew, and for only $8.25 (first time you pay a deposit fee of a few bucks, after that it's the list price as long as you return the growler) couldn't pass up.  Also found out that they have these at Whole Foods, so you can still get great brew without having to travel to the bar every time you want it.\n\nFood was pretty good as well.  had the Muffuletta sandwich and fresh cut fries.  I have a lot of family from the NOLA area, so I tend to hold this sandwich to a pretty high standard, and they did a great job at meeting it.  Sandwich was hot, right mix of ingredients, and the fries were not oily.  The sandwich set me back $10, but worth every bite.  My buddy got the oyster po' boy, and said it was one of the best he'd had in a long time.\n\nWhy not 5 stars?   The service was pretty bad.  There was only one bartender, we had sat off to the side to avoid the crowded spaces at the bar, and he all but forgot about us for around 20 minutes.  While I appreciate his honesty about it, the place wasn't busy enough for it.  He did make up for it after that, and was very attentive.  \n\nAll in all, a great experience, and I look forward to going back to try their next round of seasonal beers (which were fermenting that day) and to check out the changes to the seasonal menu as well.",

                    "text": "First, a note - I've never been upstairs to the Soiree Room, which has a different menu and is more expensive, so this only applies to the downstairs Monday Club Bar, which is more casual, and which I love. My husband and I actually had our wedding reception there and it was perfect. The decor and ambience is fun, festive and memorable. All our guests commented that the food was the best they've ever had at a wedding - everything from the hot date appetizers to the spring pea soup to the entrees to the wedding cake (vanilla cake with lemon curd and cream cheese frosting). In particular, the hangar steak entree was ENORMOUS (almost too much!) and so tasty that my relatives still talk about it even though the wedding was over 2 years ago. The service was impeccable. During cocktail hour, the servers made sure to set aside a plate of appetizers for my husband and me, knowing that we'd be doing so much mingling that we'd forget to eat. When one of our guests broke a chair (by sitting on it - very embarrassing), they had another one under him before you even knew it. Another of my guests was a jazz singer and we asked her to perform a few songs during the early part of the evening. When she sat back down she started eating, but one of the servers noticed that her entree had gotten cold. He immediately went to the kitchen and brought her another one, without even being asked. All through the night the service was attentive and unobtrusive, right up to the clean-up, when they had all our candles and flower vases etc packed up for us and ready to go while we were still finishing up dancing.\nWe have gone back there several times and the food has always been very good, if not great (the steaks are always great), and the prices are reasonable (again, this is the downstairs room).                     "text": "Want a tasty, wallet-friendly meal with attentive service? THIS IS THE PLACE to go! If you are looking for authentic Thai food similar to the kind you are used to in the Bay Area, you must try Thai Classic. Don't believe me? Since I lived in San Luis Obispo for so many years, I was fortunate enough to try an assortment of things on the menu. First time here? Also, this place has the BEST water refill service I have ever experienced. I swear, no matter how spicy the food is or how much you are trying to rehydrate yourself after a long night \"downtown\" you will never see the bottom of your water glass. \n\nSpice Factor: They will always ask you how spicy you want your food....mild, medium, medium-spicy, or hot!!! I love spicy food and I would still tend to go for medium-spicy. All you daredevils be forewarned...grandma in the back will knock your socks off if you want off the charts spicy. Just make sure you have plenty of water and lime around to help the three-alarm fire in your mouth.\n\nPrice: I you go at lunch, you can have a complete meal with wonton soup, mini house salad, and an entree with rice for about $10 including tax. Not bad at all. Dinner is very reasonable as well and everything is served family style. \n\nLocation: Situated near the corner of Higuera and Santa Rosa, just behind Firestone's Grill, the location doesn't get any more convenient than this. \n\nAll in all, I highly recommend giving this place a try next time you are craving some great Thai food in SLO.",

                    "text": "Environment:\nCausal and simple. Order at the cashier, they bring your food to your table. Bus the table yourself or leave the dishes there. The cashiers are always polite and repeat your order to make sure they get it right (they've never messed up an order!). The place is small; the salsa bar is the same counter as the cashier is the same counter as the soda bar. \n\nFood:\nI work right upstairs from El Metate and I am addicted to this place! I HAVE to go in at least once a week. Their lunch specials are always great: two tacos with beans and rice plus a large drink for $7.99, chile relleno and a tamale, two enchiladas, the list goes on...\n- Chicken tacos are awesome. The meat is dark meat, whole pieces, not like dry shredded meat some places servce. The seasoning is salty with a lil kick. On top is a generous heap of green leaf lettuce (no cheap iceberg!), tomatoes, and shredded cheese.\n- Guacamole is four stars. It's good in the sense that the consistency is good, the seasoning is good, onion to avo ratio is good, but where is the chile? No kick! I need a little life to my guac, or else it's just avo sauce. But let me tell you, there are plenty of days I only order the guac and chips for lunch. It's a lot - comes in a small styro container and only $2...which is unheard of!\n- Their burritos are okay. I can't speak to burritos much cuz I'm just not a fan of flour torts or the rice/bean/meat combo.\n- Enchiladas are great. Filled with a heap of meat or cheese, then gooey on top with more cheese and red sauce. Their tortilla always remains in tact and has that good chewy-ness to it - never soggy.\n- Chile rellenos are amazing. Their cheese is go tasty and perfectly melted. Which leads me to my next point...\n- Their food is always served at the correct temp. The meat is hot, lettuce is cold, and when served together in a taco, the flavor and temp combo of both is awesome.\n- Each table is served chips and salsa. Their salsa could be better - it's watery with mainly onions. I reco going to the salsa bar and using your own choice of dipping sauce.\n\nWhy four stars?\nLove the food, love the people. It's a great spot for a good lunch that won't take a long time, is fairly inexpensive, and is always prepared fresh to order. Try this place at least once and I'm sure you'll come back for more!",

                    "text": "Came to Grange with some friends late on a Thursday evening during Restaurant Week.  This was my first visit, and I had heard all about how Grange focuses on locally-sourced, sustainably-farmed foods.  I knew that Grange was also a fairly pricey restaurant, which is why I have never visited until now.\n\nWe were seated on the first floor at a small table and I noticed the dining area was quite small and cramped, but since it was relatively deserted that night (surprising to me since its Restaurant Week), it wasn't much of an issue.\n\nThe first course was a simple salad with vinaigrette dressing.  I was really underwhelmed by this.  The most I could taste was the pepper the waitress sprinkled on top of it.  It needed more dressing.  Overall just 'meh'.  For the main course I had chosen the whole-grain risotto.  This was actually my first time having risotto so I didn't know what to expect.  It came served with green beans, radishes, and I believe rhubarb.  While it was nice and hot when it got to our table, I found it to be extremely tasteless.  It really needed salt, which they don't leave for you on the table.  I was only able to force myself through half of it before my friend gave me half of her chicken breast (which was delicious) to eat.  The dessert course was a strawberry shortcake, which was alright I guess.  Nothing special, and the presentation was uninspired.\n\nOverall I was pretty disappointed with Grange.  In addition to the food falling flat, the service wasn't good.  After placing our drink orders we waited at least 20 minutes before receiving them and being able to order food.  Then, the waitress brought the main courses out while we were still finishing our salads!  I didn't think this meal was worth the $25 'reduced' rate, I can't even imagine how much the full price is.\n\nI thought Restaurant Week was a chance for (generally pricey) restaurants to lure in new customers by wowing them with what they can offer.  If that had happened I could have told all my friends and family how much I loved the food, and I probably would have gone back.  I wasn't wowed and now I've already told a bunch of people I know about my experience.  I'm disappointed you couldn't have put your best foot forward, Grange, because I really wanted to like you!",

I have been fighting off a cold for weeks and have become addicted to soups, so this was the perfect fit.\n\nThe location is right on Bancoft so be prepared to see a mixture of UCB students and tourists checking out all the great cafes, stores, boutiques, bookstores, etc.\n\nWe scored a great parking spot right our front and must of got there right before there lunch rush, because there was no line.                     "text": "Oh Sprinkles, how you have spoiled me! Before this Sprinkles opened, I was already anticipating for its arrival months ahead, but I didn't venture in until two weeks it had opened because I just knew the lines would be ridiculous. The marshmallow goes SO WELL with the moist chocolate cake. \nMOCHA: This flavor was pretty decent, but not my favorite. The coffee taste to it was pretty strong, though!\nHOT RED VELVET: I believe this flavor is limited, but I didn't really care for it. It tasted like the Hot Tamales candy, which was weird and too spicy and overpowering.\nVANILLA: I've only had this when it was given away for free at UCSD events, which means they had been at least a day old. I can't really speak for how it tastes fresh, but I don't think I would spend $4 for just a vanilla cupcake anywhere.\nLEMON COCONUT: This flavor is very light and has the perfect lemon flavor that I find is often hard to achieve. This is a solid pick if you're looking for a medium between fancy and simple.\nRED VELVET: This is the best red velvet cupcake I've ever had. It was SO MOIST and the cream cheese frosting was thick, but not overpowering at all. \nSTRAWBERRY: My friend got this for me for a BOGO deal but I didn't have a chance to devour it until a day later, so it was not as moist. It's a unique flavor, but not the best.\nS'MORES (BY BLAKE LIVELY): YUM. This is one of the best cupcakes from Sprinkles, but too bad it was only for a limited time. The \"toasted\" marshmallow topping was so fluffy and yummy my friends and I could not help ourselves from digging in while we were waiting for the bus. There was a graham cracker cookie layer at the bottom that was a nice surprise.\nBROWN SUGAR PRALINE: Hands down THE BEST flavor I've had from Sprinkles thus far. The caramel cake was super moist and the frosting was to die for! I love brown sugar and the caramelized flavor really stood out. I know it sounds like I've tried lots of flavors before, but it's because I take bites out of friends' cupcakes or I take advantage of BOGO offers or free cupcakes during Sprinkles' birthdays. I know they have free cupcake promotions on Facebook (ie., speak a certain \"word of the day\" to the employee or participate in their \"bring a sister/friend/etc\") for a certain number of participants. Get free cupcakes from FB promotions or special occasions, but prepare for a long wait!",

                    "text": "I really wanted to like Pod.. I really, really did. It was highly recommended by our server at Continental Mid-town and we were intrigued by it from several visits to Mad Mex next door. I knew that the Borgata's Chef Michael Shulson, who now owns Izakaya, used to work here and has quite the pedigree. The menu of Pan-Asian fusion cooking, of which I am usually a fan, looked delicious and intriguing. I had no idea that Pod had been around for more than ten years, as it looks brand new from the outside. Unfortunately for us, like Cirque du Soleil's 'Dralion' that we saw earlier that day, we left sorely disappointed. I'm getting ahead of myself here though.....\n\nI wasn't sure what to think of the ultra-modern, multi-colored, almost futuristic look of the bar and dining room. Quite honestly, while I was intrigued from afar, once inside I was kind of put off by the whole concept. Then, inexplicably, the place grew on me. It reminded me of a sophisticated, underground spaceship dining room.. chock full of odd, off kilter furniture and big party booths with buttons that allow the guests  to change the ambient lighting and smaller \"pod\" booths carved into the wall; not to mention a CONVEYOR BELT of endless sushi at the sushi bar! \n\nI think the same reasons I generally enjoy Stephen Starr's restaurants are the same ones for which other's don't.. the ultra-modern dining rooms, the young, boisterous crowds, the forward thinking cuisine.. I really 'get' it and just think some others do not.\n\nThat being said, the food here fell flat. Flat on it's face. This was one case where style certainly didn't equal substance. I honestly didn't remember what entr\u00e9e or appetizer I ordered and had to text my lovely girlfriend for a lot of the details of this review. We boxed up almost the entire Pad Thai to bring home with us and I felt utterly disappointed about the experience. \n\nBut let's back up a bit and discuss our meal. We entered and were seated immediately in the dining room at a table for two.. no wait. The restaurant was rather quiet, but it was a bitter cold night in late February. I recall them having some special 'mock' tails and we both really enjoyed our 'Vanilla & Ginger Soda' or whatever they were at the time. Unfortunately, at the time I am writing this review, they are apparently no longer on the menu.\n\nOur server was quite knowledgeable and made some recommendations as far as appetizers. We started off with the Crab Spring Rolls with sweet chili dipping sauce and Dim Sum Pork Dumplings with white soy dipping sauce. Both entrees were poorly executed and lacking in flavor, especially the Crab Spring Rolls. The only thing that made the Spring Rolls edible was the sweet chili dipping sauce. Yuck. The Dim Sum Pork Dumplings were only slightly better, and again, enhanced only by an overly salty dipping sauce.\n\nVery disappointed with our appetizers we pulled back on our ordering, whereas we normally would have splurged. We decided to share the Shrimp Pad Thai Noodles with red chili, peanuts, and mixed vegetables. The dish came out cool instead of piping hot, and the noodles were poorly and unevenly cooked. After only a few bites, I believe an overly aggressive busboy came to remove the plate and box up our entr\u00e9e. \n\nSpeaking of the busboys.. man alive! They are like vultures circling your table relentlessly asking if you're done with your dish, even when there is still food left on the plate! It happened to us not only with both appetizers, but with our entr\u00e9e as well! It made for a very uncomfortable and rushed meal.. one in which I am in no hurry to return to. I'd like to say I'd be a little more tolerant of this behavior if it was a Friday night and the place had a two-plus hour wait, but as it was, it was a freezing cold night in the middle of February and the place was nearly deserted! Let us enjoy our meal for crying out loud!\n\nThis is the first meal in a really, really long time that I was disappointed by. Disappointed may not even be a strong enough word, and two stars is REALLY stretching it. Service was good if super rushed, the 'mock' tails were tasty, and the d\u00e9cor grew on me, but overall.. the place was a definite \"eh\".\n\nThe menu looked SO good online, the sushi, the cocktails, the sea bass entr\u00e9e, the mandarin shrimp stir fry, crab fried rice, the Kobe steak appetizer cooked on a hot stone.. just a big letdown in my book.                     "text": "For me, Small Word was THE coffee shop when I was too young to go the pub and the cool place to go and hang out before coffee shops were popular - well before the Starbucks craze.  Virtually everything about Small World, I love.  From the atmosphere, to the baristas, food, and coffee, Small World is THE quintessential college coffee shop that helps make Princeton, well, Princeton.  Without SWC, the town would certainly be missing some of that charm.\n\nWhen I was going there regularly, they were open later - which my friends and I loved.  I think they stayed open until 12:30am or 1am on the weekends and were open at least until 11pm during the weekday.  If they still had those hours, I'd probably go there more often when I'm in town visiting.\n\nMornings, of course, are where they are the most crowded and, as others have noted, it does have \"out the door\" lines sometimes.  I've never been bothered by the lines per se but on crowded nights, it could be hard to get a seat if you're in a group of 3 or more.  I've been going to SWC well before they opened up the food section on the left side which has soups and sandwiches - plus some breakfast items that aren't in the main case.  It's a welcome addition if not for the extra seating but certainly for the extra food stuffs they make available.\n\nI'm not a big fan of the live music they bring in, though.  Its not that the music is bad - far from it actually.  It's just louder than I like; for a small place, you don't need a lot of volume and I end up shouting at my friends to have a conversation.  When the bands aren't there, however, the noise level is a nice - perfect of having a conversation but still getting the sense that the place is bustling.\n\nI've always enjoyed Small World's coffee much more than Starbucks.  I've always thought Starbucks' coffee was too acidic for my taste and not smooth enough.  SWC's brew, in my opinion, is spot on; smooth, flavorful, just enough boldness, and without the acidic taste that poisons many of Starbucks' blends.  The tea selection is large and varied so if you're a pond jumper, you'll be happy, too.\n\nWhat made SWC special for me, were the flavored coffee drinks they whip up for you.  They were the first to offer me a mocha, mint mocha, hazelnut mocha, butterscotch mocha, and many other flavored lattes.  Their syrup selection is pretty large and it makes the experience new almost every time you order.\n\nHow you order and how they serve also unique.  If you get it go, you select your size (single or double) and they give you the customary paper cup.  But if you stay inside, they serve you in glassware - a nice touch that adds to that special something that makes them the coffee shop of Princeton.  One thing to note: you can ask for large cup of coffee and they'll call out something totally foreign to most.  Don't worry, chances are they know exactly what you want but apply their own name to it.\n\nOne special drink that I love - that doesn't exist anywhere else - are their double sticky ciders.  It's a large hot cider with a cinnamon stick added but because they use local cider (Terhune's I think), its fresh, thick, and just perfect.  No other place I've been to serves lit like they do.\n\nSmall World Coffee, as I've said, is THE coffee shop to visit in Princeton.  From their food, coffee, tea, and ciders, they have everything you want and nothing you don't.  I highly recommend them for all your caffeinated needs.",

                    "text": "I wish I could give half stars because this place is a pretty solid 3 and 1/2 stars. Not quite 4 stars for a couple of reasons, but definitely a little better than 3 stars.\n\nInside--very clean, cozy, cute. Good chinese food place to actually sit down and eat--it's a real restaurant.\n\nService--very nice, very attentive, and very polite. \n\nFood--All food was served piping hot and freshly made. During opening week, there was a line literally out the door with mobs of people waiting to be seated and the bar area was standing room only. One month later to today, I decided to stop here for lunch around 11:30 AM when there was no wait to be seated. The manager opened the front door as I entered the restaurant and directed to the hostess stand for immediate seating. \n\nThe layout of the place has the bar area in the front, open dining room & \"dancefloor\"  with speakers & disco lights in the center and a greenhouse dining room to the westside of the building. There's also a small pirates playground outside in back for the lil kids!\n\nI am very familiar with their menu since I dine at the Joe's Crab Shack near my home quite often and been to other locations in TX and CA several years ago. They offer mostly seafood dishes, sandwiches, chowders, and appetizers at moderate prices, as well as a variety of crab steampots, which are on the pricier side. \n\nFor lunch, I ordered the Blackened Wahoo Sandwich ($11.69) with Fries and a Classic Steampot ($22.99*), which was served to me about 15 minutes. The waitress put a bib on me and as the steampot was served, was told to prepare for a \"crab facial\" as the lid was lifted off the pot and the whiff of steamed crab legs puffed out. The fries were salted and crispy golden. \n\nThe Classic Steampot had dungeoness crab, snow crab legs, boiled shrimp (peel & eat), sweet corn on the cob, spicy sausage, and boiled small potatoes. The crab was pretty good and easy to crack open. However, the potatoes and corn on the cob were very firm and the steampot could've used some more hot water to soften the texture of the accompaniments. I enjoyed a Classic Steampot exactly one week ago at the Methuen, MA location and the food was steamed perfectly there.\n\nAs I was eating, the charismatic staff did a dance routine together around the perimeter of the center dining room floor with party lights and music blasting over the speakers. I actually finished off the food in one sitting and the waitress was ready to give me a takeout box (not needed today).                     "text": "This is one of America's best breakfast joints.  \n\nThe food is awesome and always a little different, depending on what is on hand your homefries might come with extra broccoli or you might get a whole banana on the side.  They always use just the right amount of butter and oil to fry up the delights served here.  The coffee hits the spot, and the waitpersons are eager to bring water for those patrons parched from a night of drinking.  I strongly recommend trying the sausage, egg and cheese sandwich, even now, thousands of miles away, I can picture the buttered bread collapsing around the hot cheesy links and the delicious scrambled egg inside.  The eggs benedict is also real good, and sometimes I skip breakfast and go straight for the cheeseburger, which is actually a patty melt!\n\nService is a cut above most Cambridge restaurants.  They are pretty much run by one family, the children, polite and friendly serve and wash the dishes, the father, as many men now do, is in charge of cooking, and the matriarch runs the show.  She is very friendly, but as the boss she has no time for shenanigans or people keeping the door open when there is a blizzard outside.  They usually remember who you are too, depending on how busy it is, although that means you have to tell them you don't want 'the usual.'  \n\nLocation is lovely too, right in Cambridge's grit square and only steps from the red line it is easy to see why this place gets so busy on the weekends.  It is across the street from the Middle East and T.T. the Bears or whatever that place is called, and it is always fun to get one of the window booths and watch the different types of musical groups getting setup for the night ahead.  \n\nThe clientele is a more or less inoffensive cross-section of central square's rising star.  You might see more people you know than you'd expect for such a small place, but if any particularly unsavory characters from your past appears in the booth next to you, well take another bite of your sausage, egg and cheese sandwich and forget about them.  There must be quite a few harvard and mit students since the place was significantly less crowded when the students were out on break.  \n\nTiming is the one thing that sucks about his place.  They don't open until 8:30am, so if you work, you can't eat there during the week.  On the weekends you'll never have to wait if you get there before 9:30 and usually after 12pm you are safe too, otherwise I have never waited more than 15 minutes for America's best breakfast.  \n\nThe art on the walls comes from Out of the Blue gallery, so if you like their work then you'll like this art.                     "text": "Disclaimer:  This is a review only for the Bayou Bends Museum which is just a small part of the MFA.  \n\nI came here a few months ago for an event that was just stunning.  They had it lit with nice, ambient lights that provided the perfect atmosphere to enjoy the gardens and the buildings.  There was quiet music, wonderful food (with a great waitstaff), and free access to this part of the museum.\n\nThe grounds are incredibly well kept and it is the kind of place that makes you want to bring your camera and a macro lens.  All the vibrant colors make me wish I had a green thumb.\n\nThe building itself has been preserved well, though the lack of a tour guide was a bit disconcerting.  There isn't nearly as much information on the walls as I'd like for a museum, but it was fine for just a quiet event.  \n\nI'd like to come back again and see if I can get a guided tour of the house.  It is small and would only take about an hour to see everything in detail, but I think it would be worth it.  On my list of things to do is check out the other campuses of the MFA.\n**********************************************************\nOkay, I finally checked out the rest of the MFA and was pretty impressed.  Not enough to give it that extra star, but enough to become a patron.  \n\nBeing in such a large city has many advantages and our museum showcases a great one--we get some big name shows in town!  Since I'm not a music person, that venue never does much for me.  But the fact that we can get things like the Lucy exhibit at the Natural Science Museum and the Miwa Yanagi at the MFA makes me a happy camper.  \n\nEveryone is incredibly friendly, the exhibits are fantastic, and parking is pretty cheap ($3) in the garage.  Thursday nights has free general admission and it just doesn't get better than that.  Especially if you have kids and want to have a fun, educational, and cheap trip, there isn't much better in Houston.\n\nThe other great thing about the MFA is the amazing gift store.  I mean, there were books EVERYWHERE!  We were in heaven.  It took more will power than I knew existed in my body to walk away without buying one single book.  And there were a lot to choose from.                     "text": "OH. MY. GOD.\n\nSome context- I am a misplaced Southerner, having grown up in North Carolina, who has been living in Boston for almost nine years. So when I walked in and saw boiled peanuts.... and Virginia country ham... and spoon bread... and motherfuckin' all-you-can-drink sweet tea... well, you can't blame a man for a-whoopin' and a-hollerin', can you?\n\nI am not entirely exaggerating when I say that I have been dreaming of a restaurant like Hungry Mother the entire time I've lived here. It's a little slice of home, combined with some serious French cookin' chops. The chef is an Appalachian Virginian who managed to escape (and believe me, that is a rough place) to the New England Culinary Institute. He didn't forget where he came from, though, and thank God for that because who needs yet another French or fusion restaurant?\n\nI started my meal with some boiled peanuts. They were fresh and not at all salty, which was certainly different. My wife said \"it's almost like eating a vegetable!\" Me, I could've used some more salt... ok, a lot more salt, but I will freely admit that I like my boiled peanuts to taste like a salt lick. The pork rilletes were coarse, not smooth, and seriously smoky-porky- I think there was a lot of belly meat in there. Good stuff. \n\nFor an appetizer, I had a big ol' plate of the prosciutto of the South, Virginia country ham. Man alive! Good stuff. Sliced nice and thin, with some good olives and a fig compote, it was heaven on a plate. I paired my ham with the Champagne of Beers, a steal at only $3 a bottle. My wife enthusiastically tucked in to a bowl of shrimp and grits. Now, I have eaten the archetypal shrimp and grits at Crook's Corner (where Bill Neal invented the dish) so to me they weren't that exciting- too soupy. The ham was a nice touch though.\n\nFor my entree, I rocked out with my rib out- braised pork shoulder with one single perfect smoky rib and grits. That rib. Let's just say that pig did not die in vain. Intensely smoky, super rich pork flavor. The grits were very good- not Quaker out of a bag, but definitely something like Anson Mill stone-ground grits with a nice chunky texture. My wife had the roasted chicken with spoon bread. SPOON BREAD, folks! I haven't had that since my grandma cooked it for me when I was a wee one. The chicken was moist, but with a nice crispy skin and subtle herb flavors. \n\nWhew! I think that's a sufficiently exhaustive accounting of our meal. I will be back, that's for damn sure, and in the hot summer months I will drink buckets of sweet tea. Speaking of which, the bourbon, limoncello, and sweet tea cocktails is not to be missed- neither is the sorghum mint julep. Although if I tell my Mom I went to a restaurant that charges $9 for a drink made with what is essentially Karo syrup (\"that's for poor people!\") she'll laugh her head off. I'm looking forward to trying more of the cocktails, which are inventive but grounded in traditional cocktail-making, and aren't 27 different combinations of flavored vodka.\n\nSo anyway, Yankees, Southerners, Hatfields, McCoys- check out Hungry Mother. It's the most exciting addition to Boston dining I've seen in ages.",

                    "text": "First of all, I  used to work here, but that was after I became a regular at this joint. \n\nDue to the location, Sushi Niichi mainly serves the UT crowd and this reflects on their price and fish selection. However, do you really feel like paying bills at Mikado, or Musashino, or Uchi 2-3 times a week? \nGood luck with that. After all, it would be really boring if all sushi restaurants in Austin serve you in the same style with the same fish from the same supplier in Houston and Dallas. \n\nSushi Niichi is cute for its own reason. It never tries to be cool, nor yuppie. It's simply more like a family-run small restaurant where servers/owner/sushi chefs remember your first name, what you always order (we didn't say you are boring), and what you dislike, even though you don't blow hundreds of dollar each time you are here. \n\nNow we can proceed to what the goodies are at Sushi Niichi, shall we?\n\nFor sushi rolls, they do have a good VARIETY. I mean it. On the top of my head, I'd suggest:\nblue moonlight,  spider, crazy, tiger eye, volcano, hard rock, strawberry, Hawaii, golden dragon, and godzilla (see, I wasn't lying when I said I used to work here). \nEach of them packs different kinds of fish and may contain seafood tempura (soft-shell crab or shrimps). Even I self-nominate as hardcore sushi eater, which means I usually care very less about sushi rolls, I can still tell you that these specialty rolls are the shit. As for the tastes, you gotta go there and order by yourself to figure out. I simply would not spoil the fun of discovering great flavors with your own palate. \nThe last thing, please, it's ok to love the simplicity of california/philly roll, but wouldn't you like to try something else to make your sushi diary more interesting?\n\nEnough mumbling, below are the former employee's recommended items at Sushi Niichi. I'm very serious so hopefully you will at least try them.\n\nAppetizer: Calamari, Gyoza, Agadashi tofu, teriyaki style beef stake\n\nSpecial rolls: blue moonlight, spider, crazy, tiger eye, volcano, hard rock, strawberry, Hawaii, golden dragon and godzilla. \nFor vegetarian, veggie tempura, tofu tempura, jade and garden\n\nNigiri/sashimi: depends. Salmon and hamachi are always good. \nWhite tuna (binnaga) serves with slow-roasted crunchy garlic is a must try. \nIf you like salmon roe (ikura), you need to order it. Why? Because unlike some other places, where they count how many ikuras are put down in your sushi (really, kyoto, it's nothing personal),  here it is PACKED with these little eggs. \nRegular shrimp (ebi) cannot satisfy you? Go with the sweet shrimp (ama-ebi). It's served raw and the head/tail parts are deep-fried-crunchy-goodies. \nFor better value, order combo A (five pieces of nigiri with soup and salad), sampler c (8 generous pieces of sashimi), and chirashi's (seriously, I heard some people bitch about the price here. You got to be kidding me. Would you please name any other decent sushi place in Austin serve chirashi below USD15?)\n\nBeer/sake: Kirin, Sapporo, and Asahi are served here. I've always been a Sapporo and Asahi fan. Cold sake are available in draft or ginjo style. Hot sake is available as well.\n\nDessert: Japanese ice cream, mochi ice cream, banana/ apple tempura with ice cream. You will find a way at  to satisfy your sweet tooth.\n\nHidden daily/weekly specials: They have fatty tuna (toro), semi fatty (chu toro), mackerel (saba), octopus (tako), sea urchin (uni) and albacore tuna from time to time Ask your server or sushi chef.",

                    "text": "Blue Nile is located right on campus, but tucked behind Potbelly's sandwich shop in the back an on alley with very very VERY limited parking out front.  But even after a long walk on a hot summer day, I showed up at Blue Nile's front door knowing that it's going to be well worth the sweat (especially since I knew their A/C would not be cranking, but then again, who needs cool air when you can have some delicious spicy food!?!).  Here's the trick to almost guaranteeing yourself a satisfying meal at Blue Nile - ORDER THE SPECIAL!  Their specials are under $12 after tax and there's enough food to get your belly full and still walking away with a doggie bag (if you're not busy stuffing yourself because it's just too yummy to stop eating).  The Lamb Shank is tender and scrumptious (note to self - must try to figure out what is used to marinate it)!  I've had beef (usually ground beef), chicken, lamb specials and have never been disappointed (wish I had written down all their names so I can share here).  The Arabic Salad is great for summer, cucumber and tomato chunks sitting in a cup of lemon juice and minced cilantro, just what I needed to cleanse the palate and cool down a bit.  The Lentil Soup is good, tastes like it was made just before I showed up.  Chicken Shawarma sandwich comes in a pita (dry and not greased, which is how I like my pitas) with onions and tomatoes on the bottom and marinated chicken cubes on top, the Tahini sauce is what really tie the ingredients together.  If ordered as a meal, it would be the chicken on a plate of rice.  Speaking of rice, their rice is very flavorful just by itself, mixing that with whatever sauce that comes with the protein or vegetables of the dish (depending on what entree you get), it will keep getting better and better.  My only gripe about Blue Nile is that I wish they use fresh corn, green beans, and carrots instead of canned ones, but I can imagine using pre-made ingredient instead of having to prepare for fresh ones every day on top of having to mix a million spices together to marinate/soak/rub the proteins and other fresh veggies like eggplants and okras can be overwhelming in that tiny kitchen of theirs, so I suppose they have to choose their battle there.  If they get rid of the canned veggies and up their vegetarian options, I will have no choice but give them a 5 star, saying that I'm a fan is almost an understatement!\n\n***Oh btw, my Muslim friends tell me that Blue Nile serves Halal meat.",

                    "text": "--Kama Sutra Butter Lamb Masala--\n\nI never knew that lamb could taste like sex. \n\nI am new to Seattle and have been learning a lot in the past five months about this region's offerings and am pleased to have stumbled upon Cedars Restaurant on Brooklyn. A few weeks ago I ordered the lamb curry special at the Wild Ginger and although the meat was tender and spices balanced, they (the meat and spices) did not sing me into satisfaction, and in spite of the waiters' sincere praise of the dish, I was disappointed. So when my boss suggested that we order Lamb Butter Masala from the local Indian restaurant, while working late on a rainy Friday night, I agreed, but mostly because I was hungry and she was buying. As one must, I added Vegetable Pakora and Nan to the order.  Apprehensive about the Lamb in Seattle, I requested Vegetable Curry as a fall back plan. \n\nDisoriented by the crowd of chit-chatty patrons awaiting their turn at a table, and after elbowing my way to the take-out counter, I did not notice until returning to my car that I was carrying 2 large bags of food and only put $34 or so on the company credit card. This was a good sign. The smell of ginger, garlic, cilantro and curry inspired an even deeper hunger, and I ate all the Nan while driving the .5 miles back to the office. \n\nI picked a bottle of Ravenswood Zin (on sale) from QFC and although there was not a wine screw at the office, there was a toolbox. My brilliant and thirsty boss, with her Kiwi ingenuity, used power tools to drill a screw into the wine cork and then I took over with the prong side of a hammer and released the cork from its cramped servitude. By the time we had the wine open and paperwork moved off the conference table to sit down to uncover the take-out, it was still hot. \n\nThis Lamb Butter Masala got me tangled up inside. All tantric and tantalized, my taste buds got wet. Salivating, I licked every last buttery drop and was left satisfied in a heap on the conference chair. My throat burned (in that good way) and my temples and collarbone were damp with sweat.
