                    "text": "I am stuck at work and all I can think of is this stupid place. I should dock a star for it. But I won't. \n\nI have a long and glorious history with the Cobbler Factory. It started when I wasn't more than 3 and somehow my parents found it. It became a tradition in the Lenox house to go to the weekly CalTech family concert series and then pop over to the CF for some peach cobbler. We would then stop at a grocery store for some milk and head over to a nearby park. Some of my best childhood memories are times I ran around with cobbler syrup smeared all over my face. \n\nI don't go there a lot anymore. I live in Van Nuys, so to go there is a bit of a hike. Nonetheless, I cannot not justify heading over there from my work in Echo Park. The lovely peaches, cooked just right with the smallest bit of a snap left in them nestled in the most delicious crust you'll ever have makes you believe in a higher power. To tell you the truth, for the 18 years I've been going there I've only ever had peach cobbler. Really, why try something new when you've already found perfection? \n\nAll this from a postman with a hobby for making cobbler recipes thirty years ago.\n\nNext Day Update: So after I wrote this review I couldn't concentrate. I had to get to the Cobbler Factory. Two minutes before clock-out I couldn't stand it anymore. I gathered my stuff and punched out. \n\nOn my way to Pasadena I kept on speeding. I would be thinking about the cobbler then look down, see I was pushing 90, slow down, start thinking of the cobbler again and go back up to 90. \n\nOnce I finally got to the parking lot I was a woman obsessed. I drove around the small, but not too small parking lot to find it completely full (the parking lot serves a lot of businesses, not just GCF), I ended up parking in front of the Planetary Society house half way down the block from the GCF. \n\nAs soon as I got out of my car I could smell the sweetness in the air. I am sure there are calories in the air around the store, how could a smell like that come guilt free? I felt like a cartoon character, floating on the smells to the source. I had to keep myself from running.\n\nWhen I got there it looked a little different. Someone mentioned the dolls in another reviews, but I don't remember them before. They're a little cool, they're little \"would-have-freaked-me-out-if-I-was-three.\" The store was empty and all that was keeping me from my treasure was the glass display case. \n\nI did one of those awkward \"hello?\" and a woman came out with a tray of cobbler. Jackpot. I ordered two peach cobblers and a sweet potato pie (the pies are the size of my palm). Then I stopped myself. I've been getting peach for eighteen years, today will be the day I branch out. \"Change one of those peaches to a mix berry.\" I pay the $15.16 for the two cobblers and the pie and left. Again, I had to check myself so as not to run.\n\nAs soon as I got back to the car I popped the cobbler tops. To my utter disappointment the cobblers were not hot. It was okay though, I dealt. I tried the mix berry first. It was o.k. Nothing as special as I remembered the peach being, nothing to drive thirty minutes for. I should say that I'm not too much of a cooked berry person. The berries were tart and sweet and were the best cooked berries I've ever had, but it just didn't float my boat.\n\nI started to panic, what if the peach isn't as good as I remembered either? I cracked the top of the cobbler, dug my fork in, got a good chunk of peach with some crust on it, and quickly shoved it in my mouth. OH MY GOD! It is exactly as amazing as I thought it was going to be. I ate a third of it sitting in my car in front of the planetary society and then drove home. \n\nNone of my purchases lasted the night. I did have help from three people. I am a very, very giving person. \n\nIt's a good thing I'm not in Pasadena a lot. I'd be there all the time. I'm looking forward to the next time, but for now I am satisfied with the most perfect dessert quest of my life.",

                    "text": "The Houston Zoo...there are so many good things to say but some of the downfalls just makes it a simple \"A-OK.\" \n\nI have always loved going to the zoo except when I start to feel sorry for the animals that have such a limited space compared to the natural environment, but then I suck it up and usually enjoy my chance to have a close encounter with animals I would never be able to see in the wild. When I first moved to Houston, the zoo was definitely on my list of things to see. The first time I went was with a bunch of high school students for a field trip so I didn't really count that because well supervising high school students on a field trip does not allow you to really enjoy what the zoo has to offer. So about 2 years later, I finally came back for my \"official\" visit. \n\nThe first thing, parking sucks! I decided to go on a Sunday afternoon when the weather just seemed perfect. Note to self...never again! I would rather get there right when it opens, suffer the heat of summer or the cold of winter, than deal with the craziness of people scrambling for parking spaces and not knowing where they are going. At least the ticket line went by quickly and it wasn't a bad deal, somewhere around 10-12 bucks. I forgot what the zoos cost in California, but I believe around the same price or maybe even more. The one thing about visiting on the weekend are the multitudes of families that visit the zoo for a family outing. OK, I don't have kids, I just work with them. I don't mind them, but I do get annoyed when some people can't control their kids and their running around in enclosed spaces bumping into people and not knowing manners to say sorry or excuse me....please teach this early on, it'll pay off. The aquarium section is pretty small, but then again I realize we're in Houston. It's not really a coastal city with an abundance of native sea life. It does it's job and always makes me want to go back to research in marine biology. Annoying factor, people banging on the glass of the fish tanks. My parents would yell at me if I did anything of the sort to disrupt the animals, but there were so many kids and adults partaking in that activity. I had to get out before I started to go off on them. \n\nThe zoo has many animals and it always seems to be under construction in one way or another. There is a new addition, the Africa exhibit which I thought was going to be more extravagant and well more informational and have a lot more to it. I was very disappointed. The animal encounters were simply OK and a bit on the small side. They had a story that you were supposed to follow, but you couldn't hear the stories or really catch on to the \"myth.\" Some of the touch screen/interactive stations weren't working and once again people were simply annoying. \n\nThis rant could be because I work in the education system and when I see families going to the zoo and exposing their kids to different things, I do get excited because that's a plus for their future. But really please try to teach them while you're there. Then another kid asked if a bird was an elephant and this kid was about 6 or 7. Maybe, I'm just too critical. \n\nThe three stars: \n*The animals are great to see but I definitely would go back when it's less crowded so I don't have to deal with the hoards of people \n*Price is OK \n*Parking does suck \n*Some of the zookeepers are very interactive and will answer many of your questions \n*It's a great field trip, since many students have never been to the zoo \n*It can get pretty hot during the summer, but less people go so you can enjoy more things \n*Prices for food and beverages are a bit on the steep side but you can bring coolers and stuff so you can have a picnic of some sort \n\nAll in all...a great place for a family outing, a date, a field trip, photo opportunities.",

                    "text": "If you come here a hungry mother, you surely will not leave as one. Upon walking in, I was immediately taken by the homey (but not hokey) atmosphere and was welcomed by a wonderfully savory aroma. Well, let me cut to the chase here: this place smells like BACON. This is no surprise considering the pig is basically the high priest of Hungry Mother, and Chef Maiden certainly has a way with swine. Okay, mama's definitely hungry now!\n\nAlthough the menu at HM may not be lengthy, each item sounds tantalizing and fresh and presents a unique twist on classic Southern dishes. To tide us over, as the menu says, we started with the Boiled Virginia Peanuts. Who knew such a humble nut, the quintessential bar munchie, could become such a stellar starter? A server brought these to our table covered by another dish in which we were to toss the shells. Piping hot, these jumbo babies released a dramatic stream of steam when revealed. Sprinkled, or should I say, blanketed in good Maine sea salt, each nut, bean-like in texture and taste, profited from the salt that sticks to your fingers as you rip into the shells. All hail the profound peanut - this is the most playful starter I've had. Since we knew we had a rich adventure ahead of us, we passed on a real appetizer and decided to have a side before dinner instead. And what could be lighter than a side of cornbread doused in molasses-y butter? Well, luckily, the gritty, savory, Southern-style molded cornbread, which was delightfully brown and crisp on the outside (I think it was pan-fried), was nothing like our Yankee version and was heightened, not overwhelmed, by the melty topping of a sweet, but earthy, Sorghum butter. \n\nSometimes great apps overshadow the main dishes, but our meals were just as exciting. A play on chicken and dumplings was just fabulous and was not at all heavy. Instead of being submerged, a warm and garlicky roast chicken leg quarter with perfectly crisp skin (I'm a stickler for crisp skin) was cut into about 6 pieces and rested atop the dumplings (gnocchi), still-crunchy chunks of carrot, and still-verdant collards swimming in a beautiful broth which was not too thin, but not thick like gravy. The gnocchi was different than some might be used to: the soft French-style pillows, made like a p\u00e2te \u00e0 choux, had a great herbal quality with a slight lemony bite to brighten up this warm bowl of love. I had to choose the oft-mentioned catfish. The cornmeal coating was so very crispy and had a great texture that other breading lacks. It was seasoned fabulously but didn't at all take away from the delicate flavor of the perfectly cooked catfish. Its zippy bed of dirty rice with house-made andouille was to die for! I wanted the crisp celery slaw on top to be cold, but even warm, it did its job. The only non-harmonious element was a drizzling of flavorless paprika oil. Aesthetically, it just looked, well, oily.\n\nStuffed to the gills and wishing elasticized waste bands were socially acceptable, we couldn't leave without sampling the best desserts I've had in a while. Let the gluttony continue! Our very seasonal apple steamed pudding was warm and moist with a lovely maple taste. A barely sweetened cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche was the perfect topping. The tasty apple compote on the side also brightened the dish, but perhaps a little too much. It was very cold, a bit too acidic, and needed some cinnamon. But the apple chunks had a nice bite. It came with the BEST shortbread cookie which was salty with a buttery toffee flavor. The second dessert, a burnt caramel pot de cr\u00e8me was simple genius. The burnt caramel flavor gave it so much more depth than your average pot-de-cr\u00e8me. It was salted and topped generously with a light cocoa chantilly. It wrapped up all of the virtues of a good salted caramel. Wow, this was an unforgettable dessert (I will try to forget that the very bottom was a bit watery and that it was served with an unnecessary cherry biscotti)! \n\nNow as a food-lover, I usually do not bark about service, and I will not knock off a star, but this did leave a sour taste in my mouth (cured by the little chocolate-peanut butter oat candies given with the check). It's a small place with a big crowd, but our waiter was rushing us before we even got our peanuts. In addition, a party of two, which in the restaurant's defense had been there since before we arrived, was told they would have to leave. I'm not sure what you can do if you have people with reservations waiting; however, this was a bit off-putting and acerbic for me. After a long, hard workweek, a trip to Hungry Mother is comforting, and I don't believe anyone should be forced to shovel food down. Then again, I've never managed a restaurant...\n\nDespite this, Hungry Mother brings Southern Comfort up North, pleasing the Bostonian palate.",

                    "text": "Oh, Harvest.  I feel for you.\n\nWe've all been there.  That awkward, adolescent gawky stage.  \n\nYou're trying to pick an identity more painfully than you will cycle through them without thought during your first year of college.  You are aware, on some level, that if you pick wrong, you are doomed to six years of junior high plus high school and only getting two handjobs because of being known as \"that weird guy\" that \"I think he might bus tables at someplace downtown\"?  Or worse, \"the weird guy, the one who keeps on looking at me and it is *so* gross\".\n\nYou are trying desperately to sniff out the pavement.  Are you called to be a rebel without a cause with a shredded board?  Are you going to get known as \"that really cool guy who seems pretty smart, but he's quiet\" or \"that really nerdy guy\"?  Should you answer in algebra class?  Should you be a class clown and try to toe the line between obnoxious and hilarious?  Can you be the guy in the school who doesn't do sports *and* wears a fedora but *still* gets all the chicks?\n\nWell, Harvest, your identity crisis is just as bad.  Because you can't figure out what you want.  And I can't blame you because neither can Cambridge.\n\nYou started out as an earnest, hippie-dippy crunchy granola start-up co-op.  Everyone eagerly paid their dues and was really proud of the way you kept on growing and ignored the fact that your produce and groceries were more expensive, but hey, this is a local effort, to bring a market to the people, and if they had to dig a little deeper into their wallets for that scrappy, can-do grocer, they would.\n\nAnd over the years, Bread & Circus beat you up.  A lot.  At first, you could shrug it off.  But soon, it began to feel like you were on the wrong side of a conflict in Oz or 24, you were doomed.  But you had these great community roots!\n\nAnd you called us to rally.  \"A grocer from Texas bought Bread & Circus!  You're not going to stand for that, are you?\"  And being Cantabrigians, we cheered.\n\nAnd being the absolute whores that we are, we slowly started gravitating to the store that did have what we wanted in stock, did know what convenience food was, and would even tell us it was organic and preservative-free.  (How it can then survive flash-freezing without burning is something we didn't really want to know.)   They flattered us.  They said, \"Here, let me arrange a sexy hot plate of dinner for you for $8.\"  Yea, though we knew that your bulk flourr bins had merit, the smell of dough baked by someone else and formed into an appetizing, work-free loaf was as seductive as a Lorelei.  Whole Foods says, \"You're beautiful for caring enough about the environment and sustainable agriculture.  Here.  Let me show you what I can do for you.\"\n\nSo, you went on the rebound.  You decided to court all the Area 4 locals, the people who had wandered in twice and wandered back out confused wondering why everything cost 3 times as much as Star Market and none of the brand names matched.  \n\nYou put aside some of the bulk produce bins -- no one was buying unground wheat flour in bulk, and it's because they didn't appreciate you enough, but you can change, you can get past it.\n\nSo you stock Cheez-Its and Coca-Cola and Campbell's Soup.  You always accepted food stamps and WIC -- it was socially inconscionable to exclude anyone, no matter how impoverished, from the organic food culture.  Now you put the stickers on the door.  You sent flyers to the surrounding neighbourhoods.\n\nSome people came in.  But they wondered why you only had a single rack of Coca-Cola and most of the brand names didn't make sense, and the one time they brought home the mac and cheese, it tasted like dirt.  So, you tried to solicit their feedback.  But unlike the earnest, shiny-eyed local activists, these people did not want to join you for community meetings.  They didn't want to fill out comment cards or participate in surveys about their feelings on consumer brands.  They wanted to yell at the manager, swear on their way out the door and not come back.\n\nAnd this is where you've stayed.\n\nI wish you the best in surviving adolescence and getting a nice girlfriend.\n\nIf you want to talk about this some more, we can meet in the frozen foods section at Trader Joe's, which is where everyone who was still broke from working at non-profits or as artists went as soon as they opened.\n\nBut really, Harvest, don't even think I'm your girlfriend.  I'm not ready for that commitment.",

                    "text": "When it comes to Thai food in the University District, all signs seem to point exclusively to Thai Tom. I don't know why, but people really make a big deal about this place. Best Thai food in Seattle? Maybe if all the more spacious and comfortable ones in the area are somehow inferior. That's not to say this place is anything short of excellent, or that I doubt in its ability to stand up to the competition. The food here is simply outstanding. Whether it's a better Thai restaurant than all the other ones in town is another question, but what is certain is that you really can't go wrong with any money spent here.\n\nBecause I knew how popular this place is and how limited the seating would be, I anticipated it getting full shortly after opening. I stood outside and waited until 11:30 AM with a handful of other eager customers. By 11:35, nearly every seat was taken. It was then that I realized I was dealing with serious business. While I was lucky enough to be seated, I saw the waiter turn away a few people and ask them to come back later because there just wasn't enough space to accomodate them. I don't know whether to be impressed by that, but if they're so successful, I wonder why they can't afford to get a bigger place.\n\nThe place itself, if the other reviews haven't made it obvious by now, is constantly busy and crowded. It looks old, worn out, and generally unpleasant. But it's a restaurant and not a museum where you marvel at artwork. The air here is pretty much always thick with the smell of delicious fried food. The kitchen isn't in its own separate room way in the back and out of the public eye; the cooks make your food right in front of your eyes. Consequently, it can also get rather hot, especially if you sit by the fires. But all this food is definitely worth the trouble. No matter how long you have to wait, you can be entertained by the aroma of other customers' meals and the display of the food being made.\n\nSince so much of the fun of eating here comes from watching the cooks make everything, I'd suggest getting one of the seats at the counter near the front of the restaurant, kind of in the corner. It's a spectacular display, although not as ostentatious as teppanyaki. The cooks' hands move with astounding speed. They'll grab from the ingredients around them, crack eggs single-handedly, and noisily clatter the woks around as they perform all their cooking in a seemingly effortless manner. It's nice being able to see exactly how all this food is prepared, especially if it's obvious that it's being done by people who clearly have a lot of experience.\n\nThe menu here is something of an oddity. Instead of the usual thin and light paper menus, the ones here appear to be entirely painted on wooden planks. My first instinct was actually to take it as a joke, but I realize that it may have been a stylistic choice. I suppose they're really going for that authentic Thai feel here. From the rather brief list of hardly more than thirty items, I ordered the Phad Thai for $7.50. This restaurant is supposedly top-tier, but I wanted to get the most basic dish before venturing onward to their more \"specialized\" delicacies. I got it with chicken and three stars on the spicy scale from one to five.\n\nAlthough there was quite a long queue of customers who had already placed their orders before I could get a chance to, it's almost not a concern because it was such a delight watching the guy cooking the meals jump from making one person's dish to another. It's amazing how he never seemed to mess up, too. On numerous occasions, it looked like he was stirring the food too carelessly and would make a mess, but he always seemed to catch it in his wok. The show had an almost mesmerizing quality to it. I don't know why I get such a kick out of watching one person multitask so efficiently. It's an entirely missed opportunity if you get seated at one of the tables to the side, away from where all the action is taking place. For this reason, I would not recommend coming here with too large and cumbersome of a group. Either way, it's quite possible to get seated right next to a complete stranger here.\n\nMy much-awaited lunch arrived with the chicken Phad Thai on one side of a long bowl, a clump of white rice occupying the other side, and a wedge of lime adjacent to all this. Sizzling in front of me, it looked and smelled like quite a feast, although I couldn't help but notice that it was... disappointingly small. To be fair, it was a very inexpensive dish, but insufficient as a whole meal for a voracious eater like me. All petty complaints, because the food itself was without a doubt among the best of Thai cuisine I've ever experienced. A sweet taste was dominant with this Phad Thai; I guess they had skimped on the spiciness, but I won't hold it against them. I may have exaggerated the flaws, but they're all insignificant when you consider that this is just about as close to perfection for Thai food in Seattle to feasibly reach.",

                    "text": "There are two types of people in the world (well, three, if you count vegetarians, but we all know they're not really people): Those who eat steak, and those who eat hamburgers. I am definitely a hamburger type of girl, with the small requirement that it be a restaurant-style burger - it may not be steak, but you should still get to order it like one :)\n\nBobby's Burger Palace breaks a few rules of the restaurant-style burger, though. While you do get to choose how you want it cooked and the prices are indeed north of $6 (not exceedingly so, with the classic cheeseburger starting at $6.50), fries don't come with. And it's not a restaurant, it's a \"palace.\"\n\nYou kind of have to go to understand what I mean when I say it looks like a restaurant, feels like a bar and functions like a fast food joint. You start by ordering and paying at the register, but then after you seat yourself (after all the work is done, right?) someone suddenly shows up who looks like a server and acts like a server but is mostly just there for moral support, because if you try to order a beverage from this person, they will do something like give you an empty cup and direct you to the self-serve soda fountain. But they do bring you your food, based on the number placard you set on your table (and bus your plates away after you're done). The system might sound a little awkward, but it actually runs completely smoothly and efficiently as far as I can tell. It's probably somehow a profitable strategy, but for the unassuming customer it means no hassle of splitting the bill or paying tip.\n\nI've come on two occasions and on the first, I tried the L.A. Burger, which I thought was good but too salty (it's pretty heavily seasoned). The latter sentiment faded away as my taste buds readjusted so I was fully in burger heaven by the last few bites. The \"avocado relish\" is amazing and aptly named (it's sort of a pleasantly sweet, chunky guacamole), and I liked how instead of lettuce there were some sprigs of watercress. I also went all out on the sauces, which are in plastic squeeze bottles (the unmarked white vans of the condiment world) next to the salt and pepper shakers. I never took a bite without drizzling some chipotle ketchup or jalapeno hot sauce on it first. Because of this, the second time I went, I thought I could get away with getting the cheeseburger since I knew I'd be all about the sauces anyway. Bad idea, because the iceberg lettuce and onion were overpoweringly fresh (when have I ever complained about freshness?). I preferred the softer texture and more complex flavors of the L.A. rendition, which meshed better with the sauces.\n\nAs for drinks, I've ordered the frozen pear cactus margarita which is a complete steal at $4.50 because this thing is positively doused in alcohol, but that's about the only reason to feel good about getting it. It's the shade of peptol bismo, and tastes worse - like liquid salt. While \"pear cactus\" certainly sounds like an appealing flavor, all it did for the drink as far as I'm concerned is shock it into a color not occurring in nature, and make it \"spiked.\" I've also tried the vanilla milkshake, which unfortunately looks better than it tastes and is definitely overpriced at $5. I can see how their milkshakes might bring some boys to the yard, but I was unimpressed. I think they use real ice cream (with visible specks of vanilla!) which is commendable but as the texture is too thin it starts getting runny pretty fast... Such potential but when it comes down to it, a real wet blanket. I've had better milkshakes at Wa-wa and Wendy's! (But then again I really like those.)\n\nAs good as the burgers are, the big draw of Bobby's Burger Palace for me has to be the layout, which somehow feels both retro and contemporary, both refined and informal. Because the countertop-style tables are communal, it's more of a public space than most restaurants where you get your own isolated cove; it's kind of like a family-friendly bar or an indoor picnic area. (At peak hours, I'd recommend going with one or two friends max to find seats easily.) The Palace's appeal may be its novelty; it feels trendy and gourmet but not bougie. But it's also the kind of place that you can't go to too often without wearing it out. While I loved it the first time and would recommend it to the uninitiated (omnivores, anyway), I personally feel decreasingly enthusiastic about it with each visit - not because it has changed, but precisely because nothing has.",

                    "text": "Review note: This review is based only on their delivery service.  I have never seen the interior of this restaurant and I hope I never have to either.\n------------------------------\nI got home late last night in a pretty bad mood.  Fortunately, I had Top Chef to look forward to.  Unfortunately, I had nothing in the fridge!  Though there are several solid options for Asian delivery, I had sushi on Tuesday. Why does a place like this nickel and dime their customers? I have no clue - it might be that they are trying to maximize each sale... I don't think they get a lot of repeat business.  In addition, I noticed a pre-tax surcharge of $1.99.  Again, this is nothing out of the ordinary for such an establishment, but something to take note of nonetheless.\n\nThe order was placed at 9:50 but they did not show up until well past 11:00.  I live about 2 miles from this place - so that kind of irked me.  I know it's good for them to be able to knock out all their customers at one time, but seriously - there should be limits.   However, the delivery driver showed up with a huge smile and a charming affect.  In fact, he might have been the nicest delivery person I have ever met.  He handed me a large bag, spun and sauntered down the hall.\n\nI put my food down, washed my hands and got some ... no... I got A LOT of extra paper towel.  When I eat wings - I always end up looking something like this: http://bit.ly/UVwV.  In any event, I plopped myself down on the couch and dug in.  From here on out everything was a total disaster.\n\nI'm fairly lenient with my standards for delivered food - but even that has its' limits.  The wings were fairly large in size...but I ordered them extra hot and extra crispy.  They failed on both fronts.  On site, I expect extra crispy to be just that.  When delivered, I'll settle for something with a mild crunch.  These were soggy.  To top it off, the sauce tasted like sugar injected Tabasco; whereby, the cook had taken the liberty of removing all traces of spice.  The fries were even worse.  They were definitely wedge fries...and looked like they had been soaked in a bucket of water before getting sent out.  Again, I don't ask for much - but these were just too soggy.  Wawa uses a package ranch - I think it was Ken's but I honestly don't remember.  The containers were pretty darn small - and given the $.79 surcharge, I expected more.  Given Wawa's other shortcomings, I was not really concerned with the ranch.\n\nSo after eating a handful of wings, I decided to pop the Sprite.  I looked in the bag and found it E-M-P-T-Y!!!  I know this chaps some people - but I actually think it's a forgivable offense (if you want an unforgivable offense - go look at my review of No-Star Pizza - aka All-Star).  I am sympathetic to f*ups; what I expect in return is responsive service.  I finished my dinner and called WaWa.  The guy picked up the phone, asked me to hold, and there I sat for 2m45s.  I was pretty sure they had forgotten me - so I hung up and tried again.  Same thing - only this time - I sat for 4+ minutes.  Okay, third time is a charm? Not for me!  I tried a third time, and sat another 3 minutes before giving up.  Instead, I contacted the site I had ordered through and they emailed me back saying they had refunded the charge.\n\nI did not expect or want Wawa to run another drink out to me - but there is no way in hell that this place was so busy I needed to spend anywhere close to 3 minutes, let alone 10 minutes, on hold.  With all the other mediocre wing delivery spots in town - I do not see much of a reason to return.  The drink incident aside, the food is blah, but par for the course.  It's pretty reasonable - so that's a plus.",

                    "user_id": "58RwqJz5Y4lW9jWV0tYIFg",
                    "review_id": "LccAtpvSyQZyw40kdaQbVw",
                    "text": "Why is it that things are never as good as you remember them to be from years ago. What happens? Do you build up the memories to be something better than the actual experience... better than anything could ever be? Is it how one hangs on to youthful nostalgia, the sentimentality of which must be preserved by not allowing the present to overshadow the treasured past? Are memories real or are they dreams that are only based on experiences from the past? Are you ever going to talk about the frickin' restaurant?\n\nI first visited Bub's sometime in 1982 while on tour with a traveling rock band who were to play The Rusty Nail in Sunderland. They were a handful, and my job was to keep them on stage at night and out of jail by day. The band leader - no stranger to the road life and apparently no stranger to Bub's - actually got up before it was dark out, pounded on my motel door, and demanded that we all jump in the van and go to Bub's. In those days, if any of those guys got up before dark, they were seriously motivated. Such serious motivation was strictly reserved for acquisition or consumption of drugs, alcohol, and young girls and various combinations or permutations of the three. I was not looking forward to meeting Bub.\n\nAs I remember it, we rolled up to a corrugated tin shack in the middle of the woods. It had no windows, no sign, and smoke was billowing out of a vent in the roof. There was a door on each end of this long narrow building. I was afraid.\n\nWe walked in, and were met with an intoxicating waft of hickory smoke. There was a long row of serving tables and cauldrons stretching the length of the building. You grabbed a plate and a fork, walked through the room and pointed at what you wanted and it was tossed on to your plate. When you got to the end of the building, you pulled a beer from an icy washtub, you paid cash, and you went out the door and sat at a picnic table.\n\nI don't remember what I had. All that I do remember, beyond the previously related tale of how I came to be there, and my dim recollection of the structure, is that for the last 28 years, whenever someone would talk about this barbecue joint or that one, I'd get this strange feeling. I'd say \"Bub's,\" and then my mind would just drift away. I did know, somehow, that whatever I had there that day had been great.\n\n\"Bub's?,\" they'd say.\n\n\"Yeah,\" I 'd answer, \"it was some shack out in the middle of the woods in western Massachusetts.\n\n\"Never heard of it.\"\n\n\"I dunno, it's probably not there any more. Man. It was awesome.\"\n\nSometimes, I'd think I must have dreamed it up. All I could really remember was how good it was. in a shack. in the woods.\n\nFlash forward, 28 years... driving down Route 9 in Hadley with my newly-relocated-to-out-there GF, and as I cross Route 116 I see a sign pointing north. \"Bub's Barbecue - 4 miles.\" Huh? What? No way! I realize that we are actually near Sunderland... it must be the place. We careen up the road, my mouth watering. I had the pulled pork sandwich that day. Went back this past Sunday and had the brisket sandwich.\n\nI'm here to tell you that sometimes you CAN go home. Sometimes, things ARE as good as you remembered. In fact, some times, they're better.\n\nFor less than $10 you can get a pulled pork or brisket sandwich with a bottomless cup of soda, and the \"hot and cold buffet.\" For a few more bucks you can get a slab of ribs. Pulled pork - excellent. Brisket - awesome. Buffet - unbelievably great: french fries, hickory smoked roast potatoes, sweet potatoes, collard greens, barbecued beans, dirty rice, roast chicken and vegetable soup, Cole slaw, potato salad, pasta salad, pickled beets, corn salad, and I forget what else... The french fries, dirty rice, collard greens and smoked potatoes are particularly noteworthy. I don't want to give Bub any ideas, but a sandwich with one side and Cole slaw would be a pretty good deal anywhere.\n\nI don't know if there ever really was a windowless tin shack.\n\nI don't know if Route 116 used to be out in the woods.\n\nSeems the young folks out here never heard of a place called \"The Rusty Nail.\"\n\nAnd I still don't know what I ate that day some 28 years ago.\n\nBut, I do know that whatever it was, wherever it was, however it was all those years ago, what I had at Bub's the day before yesterday did not let me and my memories down at all.\n\nWhen does that happen in real life? Really.\n\nI guess I'll have to go back again soon to make sure Bub's is really there. I might as well have the ribs while I'm checking.",

                    "user_id": "lpeW6sw0C3rPc_t1q8IZ3w",
                    "review_id": "m0tSc64xohNUdfyNbe0TiA",
                    "text": "Why do we dine out? Everyone has a reason, whether it be a special occasion, a lack of love in the cooking department, or perhaps a feeling of duty to one's palate to experiment and delight one's senses.\n\nI find that when dining out, the best possible scenario would be to have ambiance, an engaging staff, interesting menu options, clean tastes, lovely presentation, and a general memory-worthy experience. I enjoy food because it takes me somewhere that I remember fondly or creates a new place in my mind that I can tuck into the \"lovely memory section\" of this foodie brain. Now, while this blog isn't a restaurant guide to California's Central Coast, the fact that I woke up this morning still talking about our meal last night begged for a blog expos\u00e9. I need to channel it somewhere, my husband and I have usurped all of our verbal accolades one could fathom, and my parents won't answer the phone. So here I go.\n\nLast night was our first anniversary. Well, not true entirely...it was last week, actually, but we have stretched the celebration out for one week. I recommend that. Quite nice. As our first date was in a velvet-curtained alcove at Robin's in Cambria, we thought it would be appropriate to spend our first anniversary at a sister restaurant of Robin's: Luna Red in San Luis Obispo. It was the grandest dining experience I can remember.\n\nUpon entering was a warmly lit, red-walled, bistro style restaurant. Candlelight, stylish staff, full wine bar, and lush conversation lining the walls. We sat in the back room by the fireplace and were greeted by a most engaging, professional server who made us feel as though he had been expecting us and looking forward to our visit.\n\nThe wine list had at least three of our favorite reds; the tea menu was fragrant with experimentation and unique flavors. But the menu. The menu. Art. Tapas of the spicy, raw, fresh, crispy, hot and fire variety. In-house, cured meats and olives, flavor combinations that require salivation, and an emphasis on the local. The chef is an artist. I couldn't focus on order; my eyes kept jumping from entree to salad to spicy tapas until through my glassy eyed menu coma I heard Rory say, \"You haven't even seen the back of the menu, have you?!\" Deep breath. Cheese menu! Yes, on the back of this artfully luscious menu was a cheese page. Well, cheese and salumi, actually. House-created salumis. Salt-cured and spicy, and even for this not so meaty girl, I could taste the peppery, smoked aromas and just imagine the care with which they were produced. The cheeses were listed from fresh to blooming soft (where my absolute favorite cheese appeared-Humboldt Fog), to semi firm to firm and a jubilant leap to blue. The pairings were beautiful, clean and simple. Our pungent Red Hawk was spotlighted by thinly sliced, tart green apples, candied walnuts and a drizzle of honey. A simple presentation done perfectly. Perfectly!\n\nWhen we eat out, we enjoy sharing plates and tasting lots of things, so the Tapas menu really suited us well. We ordered sashimi, which was presented with a mustardy wasabi, a really beautiful ginger bloom, juicy mandarin, kimchee and thinly sliced cucumbers. Careful. Clean. Cold.\n\nNext was the steamers bowl. Crostini, mussels and clams steamed in a chunky garlic broth of mustard, lemon, butter and white wine. Salty, flavorful, and bread-soakingly beautiful.\n\nThe Prawns Adobo followed suit with a parade of spicy. Rory is still talking about this one. Coconut buttermilk paired with a siracha style pepper sauce, succulent prawns, and topped with shoestring potatoes. This was prepared so well, and was presented in a deep bowl with a large spoon. We took JOY in eating this, and I can still taste the spicy and sweet broth. Mmmmmm.\n\nEspresso to follow, with a shred of lemon peel and a really rich cleansing of our palates. Such a great dinner. The service was just exceptional, a darker restaurant lit well with just candles and pleased people. Sometimes when I eat something, it takes me back to a place where I felt an emotion so special or noteworthy that the re-creation of that feeling just makes me so grateful. Last night's meal was that-a blending of my travels, of my independence, my childhood comfort foods, my new adventures of taste with my husband, and freshly created memories.\n\nWe ended with dessert-a banana, pecan bread pudding topped with an airy, coconut ice cream and a buttery, caramel rum sauce. It was warm, decadent, and the epitome of what a bread pudding, and the final taste of a great restaurant experience should be. I cannot wait to dine there with the people that I love and make new memories, and I am so thankful to have savored our first anniversary in such a romantic, magical gem.",

                    "text": "I love Moksha and here's why...\n\nNot only have I been employed by such a down to earth yet effortless fashionable woman since before Moksha turned 1, but the ladies and gent in which I share employment with are all very talented, intelligent people that bring different spices and variety to the table. Every single person who works here (has been here for ages!) and also has had a hand in contributing to the evolution of the store. Whether it be through buying, brainstorming, coordinating art/fashion shows, photography, design and by simply managing daily operations.\n\nWhat once started out as \"festival\" booth specializing in handmade articles from India, Thailand & Bangkok, Moksha transformed into an urban eclectic boutique. The owner and staff at Moksha are firm believers and practitioners of the d.i.y method and this is evident in the selection of their jewelry, artwork and clothing. We foster and promote the arts and fashion via art shows, stocking work from local artisans/designers, photographers and jewelry makers.\n\nI'm not sure whether people aware of the fact that Moksha introduced MANY (at one time: small/unknown/start-up) brands to Seattle such as Insight 51, WESC, GRN Apple Tree, Brownsound, Gentle Fawn, The People Have Spoken, Industry and dare I go on? It was always a treat when the buyers of other nameless locations would browse through our racks. We don't see those folks much anymore and we also don't carry most of those brands and I'm sure you can only guess why.\n\nMoksha is where your friends work, shop and play. EVERY SINGLE ITEM is hand selected and not sought after because the lastest DNR magazine said, \"this is what's HOT.\" As I like to say, we don't follow trends, we make them. Items range from $5 to $200. You can find your favorite spanish lipgloss for $5, search through the $10 bin where most items are marked at more than 90% off. Books from Upper Playground/FIFTY24SF artists: Jeremy Fish, Maya Hayuk & more are available for $22. You can ALWAYS find a handmade scarf from Thailand from about $8-12. T-shirts average about $28 for both men and women. Denim flies off the shelves around here but usually ranges from $60 to $90. Don't even get me started about the Thailand shipments! Cute cotton blouses, tank tops and dresses range from $15 to about $34 all of which, fly off the rack. Yes, some items are priced higher than others but that's because of the diverse selection. Did I mention Moksha now carries vintage shoes and sweaters???? I personally picked up three 70's euro styled sweaters for only $8 each.\n\nNow, I appreciate good, prompt service when I'm being waited on at restaurant but here at Moksha, we like to leave people to their own devices. I personally greet every single person who walks through the door on my shift and it's genuine. I'm sure you are all aware that most stores hire people to simply \"greet you.\" If you need to be hand held, told how to put an outfit together, what earrings look best on you- we are more than willing to assist you because after all, that's what we're here for but we don't know you need help because we are not mind readers- so just ask!\n\nAs for the exchange policy, we are more than willing to exchange your goods. If it is a regular marked item and you have all the original tags & receipts and is done within 14 days. (Sometimes we make exceptions, so be nice! Naturally we are also a little more lenient during the holidays.) For every reaction there is a reaction and if you wore the outfit the night before and it shows, no dice. We are not a major retailer and we are not able to send our unsold, returned items back to the companies from which they came... besides, major retailers get their items at rock bottom prices because they buy in bulk. So really, who's ripping who off? \n\nMoksha is where I shop. It's where my friends shop and I am always more than willing to share that secret with anyone who asks.",
